# Stonegate Pub Company Financing 2019 plc

**£1,644,688,000 10.75% Senior Secured Notes due 2029**

**€469,981,000 Floating Rate Senior Secured Notes due 2029**

Stonegate Pub Company Financing 2019 plc (the “Issuer”), a public limited company incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, is offering
£1,644,688,000 aggregate principal amount of its 10.75% senior secured notes due 2029 (the “Offered **Sterling Notes”) and €469,981,000 aggregate**
principal amount of its floating rate senior secured notes due 2029 (the “Offered **Euro Notes” or “Euro Notes,” and, together with the Offered Sterling**
Notes, the “Offered **Notes”). In addition, on or about the Issue Date, the Issuer intends to issue £36,916,000 aggregate principal amount of its 10.75%**
senior secured notes due 2029 (the “Premium Sterling Notes”) to the Backstop Parties (as defined herein) as compensation for certain backstop
arrangements entered into in relation to the Issuance (as defined herein). The Offered Sterling Notes and the Premium Sterling Notes are hereinafter
referred to as “Sterling Notes,” and, the Offered Notes and the Premium Sterling Notes, are hereinafter referred to as “Notes.”

The Premium Sterling Notes will form part of the original issuance and will constitute a portion of the relevant series of the Sterling Notes. The Premium
Sterling Notes will have the same terms and conditions as the Offered Sterling Notes. The Premium Sterling Notes and the Offered Sterling Notes, will
form a single series and will, together with the Euro Notes and any Additional Notes (as defined herein), as applicable, be treated as single class of debt
securities under the Indenture (as defined herein), including with respect to waivers, amendments, redemptions and offers to purchase. In addition, the
Premium Sterling Notes and the Offered Sterling Notes will have the same ISIN and common codes, and will be fully fungible with each other.

The Notes will mature on July 31, 2029, provided that if, on the date that is 90 days prior to the scheduled maturity date of the Existing PIK Facility (as
defined herein) (such date, the “Notes Springing Maturity Date”), the Existing PIK Facility has not been discharged in full, the maturity date shall be
the Notes Springing Maturity Date. The Issuer is a wholly-owned indirect finance subsidiary of Stonegate Pub Company Limited (the “Parent”), a
exempt company incorporated with limited liability under the laws of the Cayman Islands. The gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes (the
“Issuance”), along with certain other sources, will be used to, among other things, redeem any and all outstanding aggregate principal amount of the
Existing Notes (as defined herein). See “Use of Proceeds.”

The Issuer will pay interest on the Sterling Notes semi-annually in arrears on each January 31 and July 31, commencing on January 31, 2025. The Issuer
shall pay interest on the Euro Notes quarterly in arrears on February 15, May 15, August 15 and November 15 of each year, commencing on November
15, 2024. The Issuer may redeem some or all of the Notes on or after July 31, 2026 at the redemption prices set out in this Offering Memorandum (the
“Offering Memorandum”), plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any. Prior to July 31, 2026, the Issuer may redeem some or all of the Notes at a price
equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, plus a “make whole” premium, as described in
this Offering Memorandum. Prior to July 31, 2026, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the Sterling Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain
equity offerings at a price equal to 110.75% of the principal amount of the Sterling Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any; provided
that at least 50% of the original aggregate principal amount of the Sterling Notes (not including any additional Sterling Notes) remains outstanding after
the redemption. In addition, prior to July 31, 2026, the Issuer may redeem up to 40% of the Euro Notes with the net cash proceeds from certain equity
offerings at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount plus (i) three-month EURIBOR relating to the interest period in which the notice of redemption
is delivered plus (ii) 6.625%, of the Euro Notes redeemed, along with accrued and unpaid interest, if any; provided that at least 50% of the original
aggregate principal amount of the Euro Notes (not including any additional Euro Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption. The Issuer may
redeem all, but not part, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, upon the occurrence of
certain changes in applicable tax law. Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer may be required to offer to redeem the Notes
at 101% of the principal amount redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred
if certain consolidated leverage ratios are not exceeded in connection with such an event.

The Notes will be senior obligations of the Issuer and will rank, equally in right of payment with all unsubordinated indebtedness of the Issuer, senior
to all indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and effectively senior to all unsecured indebtedness of the Issuer
to the extent of the assets securing the Notes. On or about the Issue Date, the Notes will be, guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Parent and
certain of its material subsidiaries (the “Guarantors”). The guarantee of the Notes by each Guarantor (a “Note Guarantee” and, collectively, the “Note
**Guarantees”), will rank equally in right of payment with all the existing and future unsubordinated indebtedness of such Guarantor, senior to all the**
existing and future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is subordinated in right of payment to such Guarantor’s Note Guarantee and effectively senior
to all existing and future unsecured indebtedness of such Guarantor to the extent of the assets securing such Guarantor’s Note Guarantee. The Note
Guarantees will be, subject to the Agreed Security Principles (as defined herein) and the Indenture. See “Description of the Notes—Note Guarantees.”
Upon their issuance and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the applicable Security Documents (as defined herein) and Permitted Collateral Liens
(as defined herein), the Notes will be, secured by certain material assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors. The Collateral (as defined herein) also secure
obligations under the Revolving Facilities Agreement (as defined herein) and the Second Lien Facility Agreement. Pursuant to the terms of the
Intercreditor Agreement (as defined herein), any liabilities in respect of obligations under the Revolving Facilities Agreement, any Hedging Agreements
(as defined herein) and any Operating Facility (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) that are secured by assets that also secure obligations under
the Notes and the Note Guarantees, will receive priority with respect to any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any such assets.

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to The International Stock Exchange Authority Limited (the “Authority”)
for the listing of the Notes on the Official List of The International Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) and admission to trade on the Exchange. There
is no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange. The Exchange is not a regulated market for purposes of MiFID II or
UK MiFIR (each as defined below).

**ALTERNATIVE SETTLEMENT CYCLE**

We expect that the delivery of the Notes will be made against payment therefor on or about August 14, 2024,
which will be 10 business days following the date of pricing of the Notes (such settlement cycle being herein
referred to as “T+10”). Under Rule 15(c)6-1 under the Exchange Act (as defined herein), trades in the secondary
market generally are required to settle in one business day, unless the parties to any such trade expressly agree
otherwise. Accordingly, purchasers who wish to trade the Notes prior to the ninth business day before settlement
will be required, by virtue of the fact that the Notes initially will settle T+10, to specify an alternative settlement
cycle at the time of any such trade to prevent a failed settlement. Purchasers of the Notes who wish to trade the
Notes prior to the ninth business day before settlement should consult their advisors.

Union on trading and supply chains;

- inability to successfully implement our strategic and financial objectives;

- changes in laws and regulations to which we are subject or may become subject;

- inability to continue as a going concern;

- decline in beer sales;

- reductions in disposable income of blue collar workers and students in the UK;

- consumer’s preference for alternative shopping channels or locations;

- increase in subscription prices for broadcasting services;

**Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) and Other Non-IFRS Metrics**

Certain key performance indicators used in this Offering Memorandum are defined as follows:

**_Group KPIs and Other Non-IFRS Metrics_**

“Acquisition Capital Expenditure” represents payments made by us to acquire trading sites;

“Group **Adjusted EBITDA” represents the Group Pre-adjusted EBITDA excluding acquisition and integration**
costs, proceeds and/or costs incurred in relation to business interruption insurance claims, surrender premiums,
business reorganization costs, discretionary management fees, non-cash share-based payment charge recognized
pursuant to IFRS 2 (Share-based Payment) in relation to our management incentive program, pension scheme
service costs, profits and losses on disposed/non-trading sites and other non-recurring costs (such as lease
renegotiation costs with landlord in light of the COVID-19 pandemic and the amount corresponding to increase
in increase in health and safety provisions recognized by us);

“Group **Adjusted EBITDA Margin” represents Group Adjusted EBITDA divided by its revenue for the period;**

“Group **Cash Conversion” represents Group Adjusted EBITDA less Maintenance Capital Expenditure, divided**
by Group Adjusted EBITDA;

“Group **Capital Expenditure” represents the sum of our purchase of property, plant and equipment and payments**
to acquire trading sites for the periods presented, which, for operational purposes, we categorize as Acquisition
Capital Expenditure, Investment Capital Expenditure and Maintenance Capital Expenditure;

“Group Pre-adjusted EBITDA” represents the Group’s profit/(loss) for the period excluding UK income tax
credit/(charge), movement in fair value of swaps, finance cost, finance income, (profit)/loss on sale of non-current
assets and depreciation, amortization, impairment and revaluation;

“Group Return on Investment” represents, for all pubs invested during the 156 weeks preceding the date on
which we present the Group Return on Investment, the difference between the annualized (on a 52-week basis)
aggregate weekly average post-investment pre-adjusted EBITDA and the 52-week pre-investment pre-adjusted
EBITDA of those pubs, divided by the aggregate Investment Capital Expenditure invested in these pubs over the
same 52 weeks. Where a pub has traded for less than 52 weeks post-investment, we have not taken it into account
when calculating the Group Return on Investment;

“Investment Capital Expenditure” represents amounts recorded in our accounting system as capital expenditure
incurred in connection with expansion and conversion of our pubs. Amounts recorded in this manner are supported
by senior management-approved investment appraisals; and

“Maintenance Capital Expenditure” represents all of our capital expenditure that is not Acquisition Capital
Expenditure or Investment Capital Expenditure and includes, among other things, capital expenditures on kitchen
electricals and appliances (large and small), roof maintenance, business projects (e.g., wifi installations at sites,
website development, installation of point of sale machines and card readers at our sites) and certain capitalized
labor costs (e.g., costs of project managers and design teams associated with our investment projects).

**_Stonegate Group KPIs and Other Non-IFRS and Pro Forma Metrics_**

“Stonegate Group Adjusted Cash Interest Expense” represents Stonegate Group’s interest expense in cash for
the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024 in respect of its indebtedness as of April 7, 2024, assuming that such debt was
incurred as of April 10, 2023. Stonegate Group Adjusted Cash Interest Expense excludes any interest expense in
connection with our lease liabilities, the Second Lien Facility (as the interest payable under the Second Lien
Facility is capitalized) and the Platinum Facilities;

“Stonegate **Group** **Adjusted EBITDA” represents Group Adjusted EBITDA, excluding Platinum Group**
adjusted EBITDA, which consists of the aggregate site pre-adjusted EBITDA (as reported in our Leased and
Tenanted segment reporting) of each of the 1,034 Leased and Tenanted pubs transferred to the Platinum Group,
as adjusted to include insurance income and overhead costs in accordance with our agreements with the Platinum
Group;

“Stonegate **Group** **Adjusted EBITDA Margin” represents Stonegate Group Adjusted EBITDA, divided by**
Stonegate Group’s revenue, which is calculated by excluding the revenue attributable to the 1,034 Leased and

xiii


-----

Tenanted pubs in the Platinum Group from the Group’s historical revenue, as further described in Note 7 of
“Summary Historical and Pro Forma Financial and other Information”;

“Stonegate Group Adjusted Net Debt” represents Stonegate Group’s net debt as of April 7, 2024 less our lease
liability as of April 7, 2024, calculated in accordance with IFRS 16, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions;

“Stonegate **Group** **Cash Conversion” represents Stonegate Group Adjusted EBITDA less Stonegate Group**
Maintenance Capital Expenditure, divided by Stonegate Group Adjusted EBITDA;

“Stonegate **Group** **Capital Expenditure” represents Group Capital Expenditure excluding Maintenance Capital**
Expenditure incurred in relation to the 1,034 Leased and Tenanted pubs transferred to the Platinum Group;

“Stonegate **Group Freehold Property Asset Value” represents the property asset value of £2,802 million in**
respect of 2,611 freehold sites of Stonegate Group as of September 24, 2023, as determined by Avison Young
(UK) Limited;

“Stonegate Group **LTV Ratio” represents ratio of Stonegate Group Adjusted Net Debt as of April 7, 2024 to**
Stonegate Group Property Asset Value as of September 24, 2023, see “Summary— _Summary Historical and Pro_
_Forma Financial and other Information”;_

“Stonegate **Group L&T Revenue Growth (Like for Like)” represents, for the relevant period, Stonegate Group**
percentage growth in the pub level revenue from the Leased and Tenanted estate (which excludes the Platinum
Group estate) for all pubs that have traded in the estate for the current and previous period;

“Stonegate Group Maintenance Capital Expenditure” represents, the Group’s Maintenance Capital
Expenditure excluding Maintenance Capital Expenditure incurred in relation to the 1,034 Leased and Tenanted
pubs transferred to the Platinum Group;

“Stonegate **Group Managed Revenue Growth (Like for Like)” represents, for the relevant period, Stonegate**
Group aggregate change in revenue from Managed pubs compared to the previous comparable period made at all
Managed pubs open and operated throughout the current and previous period;

“Stonegate Group Operator-run Revenue Growth (Like for Like)” represents, for the relevant period,
aggregate change in revenue compared to the previous comparable period made at all Stonegate Group’s Operatorrun pubs open and operated throughout the current and previous period;

“Stonegate Group **Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA” represents Stonegate Group Adjusted EBITDA as adjusted**
for certain items including the impact of IFRS 16 (Leases), additional revenue from increase in price of drinks
supplied to Pub Partners, additional revenue from increase in price of drinks sold at Managed and Operator-run
pubs, additional procurement costs due to increase in price of drink and food products supplied, additional revenue
from new digital media (MiXR), certain energy cost savings, asset optimization, cost savings in relation to
optimization of organizational functions, additional cost of wages and salaries, reduced sales in Managed and
Operator-run pubs due to train strikes and additional adjustments in relation to asset optimization and MiXR;

“Stonegate Group Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA Margin” represents Stonegate Group Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA, divided by Stonegate Group’s revenue, which is calculated by excluding the revenue attributable to the
1,034 Leased and Tenanted pubs in the Platinum Group from the Group’s historical revenue for the period, as
further described in Note 11 of “Summary Historical and Pro Forma Financial and other Information,” but does
not include any pro forma adjustments to revenue, as discussed in Note 10 of “Summary Historical and Pro Forma
_Financial and other Information”; and_

“Stonegate Group Secured First Lien Adjusted Net Debt” represents Stonegate Group’s Adjusted Net Debt as
of April 7, 2024, less certain borrowings under our Second Lien Facility Agreement.

**_Segment Reporting_**

Further to the acquisition of Ei Group (which we completed on March 3, 2020) and the integration of the Ei Group
business segments with our business, including the conversion of pubs into different operating models and formats
so as to enhance value creation and profitability, we introduced the following reportable segments from the period
commencing on July 4, 2021:

- Leased and Tenanted, in which we have no direct involvement in the operations and which consists of
(i) Pub Partnerships, covering rental income and revenue from supply of drinks and gaming machines

xv

from our tied Pub Partners and (ii) commercial properties, covering rental income from our untied
commercial properties;

- Managed Pubs, in which we manage the site fully, taking on full operational risk and in return receiving
the full retail margin, and which consists of (i) the managed pubs operated by us and (ii) managed
investments operated pursuant to certain joint ventures entered into by us with experienced retail
partners; and

- Operator-run, in which we contract with a third party operator to manage the day-to-day operations of
the site, receiving a turnover-based fee. All labor costs are borne by the third party, but all other costs are
borne by us, and we have access to the full retail margin covering revenue from the sale of food, drink,
accommodation and gaming machine income. This segment consists of our Craft Union format.

this Offer Memorandum presents revenue, Group Pre-adjusted EBITDA and certain other metrics by reporting
segment. We eliminate intersegment revenues and costs upon consolidation and the segmental note is presented

All of our revenue is generated in the UK and is not further segmented based on location. Therefore, no
geographical segmental analysis has been provided.

**Valuation**

**_Avison Young Valuation Reports_**

Avison Young (UK) Limited (“Avison Young”) issued valuation reports dated November 15, 2023, in respect of
the valuation as of September 24, 2023 of the Group’s portfolio of 4,480 pubs, Stonegate Group’s portfolio of
3,446 pubs and Unique Group’s portfolio of 1,765 pubs, respectively (collectively, “Avison Young Valuation
**Reports”).**

The Avison Young Valuation Reports were issued in accordance with the definition of “Market Value” consistent
with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) Valuation – Global Standards, effective from January
31, 2022 (“RICS Standards”). In each of the Avison Young Valuation Reports, Avison Young has carried out
an on-site review of a sample of 20% of the properties covered by the respective report, with the remaining
properties valued on the basis of a desktop review.

The Avison Young Valuation Reports have been prepared in accordance with the definition of “Market Value”
consistent with the RICS Standards. The reports note that Avison Young’s valuation took into account the trading
and property data provided by management. For tenanted properties, it considered the net rent, barrelage and
machine income to arrive at the fair maintainable income which is then capitalized to appraise market value. For

xviii


-----

Managed pubs, it considered the fair maintainable operating profit which is then capitalized to appraise market
value.

The Avison Young Valuation Reports assume that we have supplied all information that has a material effect upon
the value of the relevant properties and that this information is accurate and can, if necessary, be verified. In
particular, as described in the reports, Avison Young:

- have assumed that the buildings are capable of being insured by reputable insurers at reasonable market
rates;

- have not made any allowance for legal fees or any other costs or expenses which would be incurred on
the sale of the property;

- have not undertaken any form of technical, building or deleterious material survey and have not reviewed,
or given warranties as to, the condition of the structure, foundations, soil and services;

- have not provided a formal environmental assessment and have not carried out any soil, geological or
other tests or surveys in order to ascertain the site conditions or other environmental conditions of the
property;

- have disregarded the value of all process related plant, machinery, fixtures and fittings and those items
which are in the nature of occupiers’ trade fittings and equipment; and

- have assumed that the property is constructed, used and occupied in full compliance with the relevant
planning and building regulation approvals and that there are no outstanding notices, conditions,
breaches, contraventions, non-compliance, appeals, challenges or judicial review.

As of September 24, 2023, the Avison Young Valuation Reports valued the Group’s, Stonegate Group’s and
Unique Group’s portfolio at £4,114 million, £3,183 million and £1,501 million, respectively.

**Overview**

We are the largest pub company in the United Kingdom based on the number of sites (4,414 Group sites and 3,380
Stonegate Group sites, as of April 7, 2024). We began our trading operations in November 2010 with the
acquisition of 333 pubs from Mitchells & Butlers and, through a series of strategic acquisitions, including the Ei
Acquisition, we are now the largest pub company in the United Kingdom. Since 2010, we have acquired
businesses and assets in order to geographically diversify our presence across the United Kingdom, providing
exposure to regional markets and a number of operating models, formats and brands that provide a diverse and
resilient financial profile. We continually evaluate opportunities to strategically acquire individual sites in
situations where those sites are a particularly good fit for our existing business.

We have a strong real estate backing based on an estate of predominantly freehold properties, approximately 81%
by number of Group sites and approximately 90% by value (as of September 24, 2023) and a Group property asset
value of £4.1 billion (as of September 24, 2023). Within Stonegate Group, which has a property asset value of
£3.2 billion (as of September 24, 2023), our freehold estate comprises approximately 76% by number of sites and
approximately 88% by value, in each case as of September 24, 2023. We have a strong presence in London and
the southeast region of the United Kingdom and have diverse operating models, formats and brands.

Our revenue is generated from a variety of sources, including drink sales (76.7% and 77.2% of our Group’s
consolidated revenue for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024) and food
sales (10.4% and 9.8% of our Group’s consolidated revenue in the same periods). We believe that our diverse,
resilient and agile business across operating models, formats and brands, led by our experienced and reputed
management team, is instrumental in driving our revenue growth. Our Group’s revenue, operating profit, and loss
after taxation on a historical basis for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 were £1,719 million, £68 million
and £155 million, respectively, and for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024 it was £916 million, £190 million and
£4 million. Stonegate Group’s revenue for the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024 was £1,594 million and Stonegate
Group Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA for the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024 would have been £411.6 million.

The pubs and bars sector in the UK experienced significant disruption due to the outbreak of the COVID-19
pandemic and the subsequent government intervention, which resulted in the temporary closure of pubs and bars,
severely impacted trading in 2020 and 2021. However, according to CGA, the pubs and bars sector in the UK has,
in the year ended December 31, 2023, recovered to similar levels as measured by sales as compared to the year
ended December 31, 2019, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with pub companies experiencing particularly strong
trading in the past 12 months.

We operate three main business segments: Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run:

  - _Leased and Tenanted: Within our Leased and Tenanted segment, Pub Partnership is our principal_
business activity following the completion of the Ei Acquisition. In addition, this segment also includes
commercial properties which consist of free-of-tie pubs and non-pub properties that are operated and
managed by third-party leaseholders on arms-length agreements. A key feature of the Pub Partnership
operating model is the tie arrangement, whereby most Pub Partners have agreed under their lease or
tenancy agreements to purchase beer and other beverages through us. The tie arrangements, along with
rental income, provide us with resilient and recurring earnings. As of April 7, 2024, the Group has 3,019
Leased and Tenanted pubs, which includes 1,985 Leased and Tenanted pubs in the Stonegate Group with
the remaining 1,034 pubs in the Platinum Group.

1


-----

  - _Managed Pubs: Our Managed pubs are owned and operated by us and derive their income predominantly_
from the retail sale of food and drinks, accommodation and gaming machines. We believe this segment
allows us to take advantage of the pubs we believe have a significant upside potential through direct
management by experienced pub managers and pub operators. Our Managed pubs are strategically
positioned to cater to different customer demographics, trends and occasions. Our Managed pubs are
classified into nine formats, Bars & Venues, Be At One, Popworld, Premium, Proper Pubs, Pub & Dining,
Slug & Lettuce, Social Pub & Kitchen and Sports Bar & Grill. In addition, within our Managed Pubs
business segment, we also have entered into 48 joint ventures with experienced retail partners. As of
April 7, 2024, we had 803 pubs operating within our Managed segment, all within the Stonegate Group.

  - _Operator-run Pubs: The Operator-run pubs are run by self-employed operators under our guidelines for_
managed pub operations, with a sports, entertainment and drink-led retail offering but typically a limited
food offering. The self-employed operator is paid a fixed percentage of revenue and is responsible for
employing all of the on-site staff. Accordingly, we benefit from low levels of operational gearing,
resulting in resilient earnings, downside protection and proportionally lower central costs to operate
Operator-run pubs. We operate these pubs under the Craft Union format, with one clear retail offer that
is drinks-led with quality beers at affordable prices, served in local, well-invested facilities, with audio
visual equipment for sports and entertainment. We believe that the structure of the Operator-run model
supports superior return on capital investment, as well as provides for higher levels of downside
protection given that we retain all revenue and meet all costs (other than staff costs, which are paid by a
self-employed operator who receives a percentage of revenue in order to do so). As of April 7, 2024, we
had 584 pubs operating within our Operator-run segment, all within the Stonegate Group.

**Our Strengths**

Our key credit strengths include the following:

**_Attractive and stable market, growing with a shrinking pub footprint_**

Prior to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK pubs and bars market demonstrated stable long-term
growth, increasing at a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 3.0% between 2015 and 2019 to reach a
total industry revenue level of approximately £29.5 billion in 2019. Following two years of disrupted business
and operations due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK pubs and bars market recovered to preCOVID- 19 levels in 2022, and CGA forecasts growth in the sector to be approximately 2.8% during the period
from 2023 to 2029. We expect that this stable market growth, coupled with a continued reduction in the number
of establishments in the sector, to be beneficial to the remaining establishments such as the Group.

We believe that we are also well-placed to benefit from the supportive supply-demand dynamics in both the
“drink-led” (or “wet”) and “food-led” (or “dry”) segments of the on-trade market (i.e. consumer businesses that
hold a license to sell alcohol on the premises). As shown below, the number of sites in the UK has declined from
2015 to 2023 by approximately 8,400 sites, with the decline in pubs and bars exacerbated during the COVID-19
impacted period. On the other hand, over the same period, the pubs and bars wet and dry market value has increased
by approximately £4.4 billion, thereby increasing the effective revenue per site by approximately £203,000 from
£509,000 in 2015 to £712,000 in 2023. According to CGA, the effective revenue per site is estimated to further
increase by 27% to £907,000 from 2023 to 2029.

The UK pubs and bars market has experienced downward trending wet volumes, impacted by the change in
alcohol consumption between different generations. According to the NHS health survey, alcohol consumption
has fallen among younger generations by approximately 15-22% from 2011 to 2021, although this has been
partially offset by an increase in alcohol consumption by older generations of approximately 5-11%. CGA
estimates that wet volumes during the period between 2023 and 2029 will remain relatively stable. However, as
a consequence of a declining number of sites, wet volumes per establishment are expected to increase at 10%
to 49 kL in 2029.

**_UK’s largest pub company benefitting from economies of scale_**

We have a high-quality and sustainable pub and bar estate. The quality of our estate is evident in our geographic
distribution and overall profile of our pubs. Our pubs are favorably weighted towards more suburban and rural
areas as well as towards London and areas in the southeast region of the United Kingdom. Additionally, our pubs
have diverse operating models, formats and brands, which we believe provides higher rental income and higher
drink sales based on a higher volume.

Our position as the United Kingdom’s largest pub company affords the business significant benefits of scale in
comparison to smaller pub companies in the United Kingdom. In terms of negotiating procurement terms, we
benefit from enhanced bargaining power with suppliers and service providers as a result of our size and
purchasing volume. In terms of operating leverage, we have higher revenue potential as our portfolio absorbs
the fixed costs associated with a pub company more effectively. Our operational expertise is a key benefit of
our scale, as it allows us to disseminate operational best practices across our estate to increase profitability, as
well as to access substantial data to inform key decisions such as strategic pricing and promotional initiatives.
Additionally, the size of our estate creates significant headroom for operational improvement across our portfolio
and value accretive capital opportunities, including the ability to convert and carry out expansionary
refurbishment, and the breadth of our portfolio allows for an efficient allocation of resources, where investment
is directed towards the highest returning opportunities.

Our diversification and significant scale position us to compete more effectively than other market participants,
delivering greater value to our stakeholders, including tenants, employees, customers and local communities.

**_Proven platform with a resilient, multi-offering business model_**

Our business is divided across three reporting segments, acting as a landlord for the Leased and Tenanted segment,
a proprietary pub operator for the Managed Pubs segment and a partner for third party operators for the Operatorrun segment.

As we are flexible in applying the format best suited to the demographic trends or customer base of a certain area,
we are able to overlay the appropriate brands and formats across our portfolio to maximize the performance of
our estate. Our multiple formats allow us to maintain a significant presence in growing cities without adversely
affecting sales at our pubs in adjacent locations, as compared to single-format operators that are limited to catering
to select target groups. Thanks to our multiple formats, we are also able to target a wide customer demographic
while being able to cater to various consumer trends.

Our multi-format platform brings diversity in terms of income sources (rental income, wholesale drink sales
and retail drink and food sales), locations (distribution throughout the United Kingdom with a weighting in

more profitable areas such as London and the southeast region of the United Kingdom), operating models
(Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run).

**_High-quality and primarily freehold real estate portfolio_**

Our Group has a strong real estate backing based on an estate of predominantly freehold properties,
approximately 81% by number of sites and approximately 90% (as of September 24, 2023) and a property asset
value of approximately £4.1 billion (as of September 24, 2023).

The estate is weighted towards rural and suburban locations, and the majority of its holdings also benefit from
being in the southern region of England, with approximately 53% of the Group’s estate as of September 24,
2023 located in that region where property prices are generally higher than the rest of the United Kingdom. Our
portfolio is well invested in with significant levels of capital expenditure, with a spend of £144 million, £140
million, £53 million on Capital Expenditure in the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, 52 weeks ended
September 25, 2022 and 52 weeks ended September 26, 2021, respectively.

Our Group has a strong track record of disposing of properties above book value and from September 28, 2020
to April 7, 2024, has disposed of 290 sites at, on average, a 23.6% premium to book value. This continues the
pre- acquisition track record of the Ei Group, who, in the ten financial years ending on September 30, 2019,
disposed of 3,371 properties at a premium to book value of 19.9%.

**_Highly experienced, best-in-class management team_**

McDowall (Chief Executive Officer), David Ross (Chief Financial Officer), Brian Magnus (Senior Partner at

Our Group is led by our Chief Executive Officer, David McDowall, who has over 25 years of experience in the

**Our Strategies**

As the business has recovered from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and is now operating in a steady
state, we intend to pursue the strategies set out below to take advantage of the attractive supply and demand
market dynamics.

**_Business as usual_**

 - _Leased and Tenanted: Within our Leased and Tenanted segment, we plan to operate the Pub_
Partnership business, our main business, in its existing form. We believe that the estate is of high
quality, having been shaped into a strong and profitable business by strategically disposing of

5


-----

underperforming, smaller and secondary assets over time. We intend to continue to invest in the
Leased and Tenanted portfolio to ensure that our Pub Partners have the infrastructure that they require
to provide the best customer experience and to increase site profitability, ensuring the resilience of our
income.

 - _Managed Pubs: Our strategy for the Managed Pubs business includes continued capital investments,_
responsiveness to industry trends, pricing improvements, labor efficiency and the implementation of
operational best practices across our estate.

 - _Operator-run: We continue to leverage our Managed Pub expertise in our Operator-run estate,_
combining best practice from Managed Pubs in a format where there is limited operational gearing.
We will continue to be innovative with the formats deployed, focusing primarily on the proven Craft
Union format.

**_Asset optimization strategy_**

We intend to maintain our commitment to asset optimization through capital investment and to capital recycling
through disposals, as we continue to improve our business performance and further increase our market share.
We have a sizeable pipeline of opportunities in our portfolio, which provides for strong investment and growth
opportunities in the future. Our commitments will be primarily focused on conversions to the Operator- run
model where we can use our flexibility and innovation in ensuring the most suitable format is implemented, in
particular, on converting the majority of applicable pubs to our Craft Union format.

We expect that our capital program going forward will be weighted towards pubs in suburban locations in order
to maximize our returns in the current trading environment. However, the scale of our potential pipeline allows
us to be flexible when selecting investment opportunities and we will remain alert to any changes in underlying
consumer trends and adjust our capital investment strategy accordingly, to the extent necessary. We intend to
capitalize on our ability to deliver market-leading operating performance across the Leased and Tenanted,
Managed Pubs and Operator-run models, particularly in light of the value creation opportunities provided by the
low operating leverage inherent in the Operator-run model. These strategies are discussed in more detail below.

Supported by our established asset management function, assuming a steady state of business and in line with
our strategy to invest in value enhancing operating models, we currently expect to convert approximately 50
pubs a year over the next 6 years from the Leased and Tenanted segment to mainly the Operator-run and a few
to the Managed Pubs segment. We have been historically successfully in converting our pubs between operating
format, with a historical record of approximately 40% return on investment for conversions during the 156
weeks ended April 7, 2024.

_Expand the Operator-run model to capture retail economics_

We believe we can create value by improving the existing Craft Union pubs and converting suitable Leased and
Tenanted pubs into the Craft Union format. We estimate that we will invest, on average, approximately £150,000
to £200,000 per pub to convert Leased and Tenanted pubs into Operator-run pubs, with high performing Leased
and Tenanted sites selected for this conversion, which benefits from the labor cost arbitrage of the tenanted
model and allows for greater control of investment, format and operations. The conversion allows us to capture
the full retail margin on food and drink sales, whilst minimizing exposure to labor costs. This would allow us
to capture Operator-run retail economics, in which we are targeting an estimated return on investment of
approximately 41% as illustrated in the chart below.

and Tenanted model, in terms of allocating responsibility to the pub operator for labor, staffing and other costs.
These pubs tend to be drink-led with no food offering and have a sports focus. We believe that the Craft Union
format is particularly well suited for drink-led pubs with lower revenues.

We generally expect these conversions to result in higher profitability. Above a minimum level of sales,

model. Additionally, through our capital investments program, whereby we estimate we will invest, on average,
approximately £300,000 to £350,000 per pub to implement these conversions, we are targeting an estimated

_Expansions_

In addition to the conversions, an important aspect of our asset optimization strategy going forward is
concentrated on investing in the refurbishment and upgrading of assets in the existing estate. The strategy
includes each of the Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run segments, with a total of
approximately 300 to 400 sites a year, at a cost of approximately £30 to £40 million each year.

The strategy is predominantly focused on the Leased and Tenanted estate, targeting approximately 250 planned
expansions a year over the next 6 years, with management intending on accelerating its investment into the
Leased and Tenanted division beginning in the 2025 financial year. During the 156 weeks ended April 7, 2024,
expansion schemes in the Leased and Tenanted segment have delivered approximately 68% return on investment. The
average expenditure for the planned expansions is approximately £30,000 per Leased and Tenanted site until
2029 (with an annual increase in line with 2.5% inflation). Additionally, we are planning on targeting
approximately 100 Operator-run or Managed Pubs expansions a year over the next 6 years.

_Disposals_

Disposals are a key pillar of our asset optimization strategy. In addition to planned sale-and-leaseback of selected
Managed Pubs sites, we aim to opportunistically crystallize value through selective site disposals, which
predominantly consist of sites that are no longer core to our conversions or expansions strategy.

The disposal strategy contributes to our business strategic objectives of deleveraging, funding growth capital
expenditure and providing an opportunity to crystalize value at attractive multiples. From September 28, 2020
to April 7, 2024, we have received a total of £158.4 million in disposal proceeds, with a total of 290 sites disposed
of at run-rate multiples of 22.7x.

**_Continuous Optimization Initiatives of Business Operations_**

We continuously focus on delivering optimization through a number of business initiatives outlined below.

8


-----

_Pricing_

Pricing is a key component of ensuring we continue to improve our margins, which has been particularly key to
our overall strategic objectives given the inflationary environment in the United Kingdom in the last 2 years, with
Consumer Price Index inflation reaching a peak of 11.1% in October 2022. Our current pricing strategy focuses
on offsetting cost inflation by raising prices via data-led strategic increases in our Managed Pubs and Operatorrun segments and maximizing price levers within the Leased and Tenanted segment.

For the Operator-run segment, we believe our pricing is currently below our peers’ pricing. Therefore, in the
near term, we are planning on capitalizing on price headroom to deliver strong price increases during the second
half of 2024, alongside a longer-term strategy to increase prices marginally ahead of inflation. For the Managed
Pubs segment, the higher-end positioning of the Managed Pubs business enables longer-term price increases
above inflation, driven by premiumization trends. For our Leased and Tenanted business, price increases are
implemented through yearly price reviews in April and are limited to CPI inflation plus 3%. Additionally, the
pricing of the rental component of the Leased and Tenanted income is supported by predominantly index linked
tenancy agreements, which implement rent increases with inflation.

_Media_

We realize the potential for use of digitalization and technology to enhance our Group’s performance and
improve our margins. Our media strategy is focused on two key initiatives, first, the “Media” initiative, which
involves the installation of digital advertising screens at our Managed sites, and second, the MiXR App, which
is a cross portfolio loyalty application that engages customers across multiple brands.

The Media component of our strategy involves installing of digital advertising screens to exhibit promotional
content at Managed sites. We aim to have installed digital advertising screens at approximately 800 selected
sites by November 2024. The screens will feature premium brands to enhance the increasing trend of
premiumization among our customers, whereby customer demand for premium drink categories has been
growing, particularly for premium lager and craft beer. The screens will also provide additional revenue from
third-party advertising media sales and content.

The MiXR App is a newly launched loyalty application designed to encourage customers to pre-book visits to
pubs in our estate, as well as display our promotional initiatives. The application has been popular since its release,
with downloads continuing to perform ahead of the rate required to achieve our target of 1.5 million downloads by
September 2024. The MiXR App is designed to increase customer loyalty to our pub estate and increase the
frequency of visits by customers.

_Cost Rationalization_

We continue to focus on improving our margins, of which cost rationalization is a key part of the wider strategy.
Significant progress has been made towards the operational improvement of our business, in particular, cost
rationalization in our head office functions, in addition to further initiatives in place to support long-term
strategic initiatives. As part of our cost rationalization strategy, we are also focused on simplifying our overall
structure, including increased spans of control, automation of processes where applicable and cost reductions.

_Energy_

Wholesale energy prices increased rapidly from the second half of 2021 and into 2023 as a consequence of a
supply-demand imbalance, following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Following this period of
volatile and elevated energy costs, we have taken steps to reduce energy consumption and otherwise mitigate
the impact of energy price volatility across our estate. There was a spike in prices during December 2022, but
prices fell back in early 2023 and have remained at levels well below their 2022 peak. However, they still remain
above their pre ‘energy crisis’ levels.

The pricing component of the energy strategy is focused on hedging energy prices to mitigate the impact of
volatility in future energy prices, with the Group hedging almost 100% and 75% of our expected electricity usage
for summer and winter 2024 and 98% and 78% of our expected gas usage for summer and winter 2024.
Additionally, to reduce consumption, we conduct periodic trainings and communication initiatives for our staff to
support reduced energy consumption.

**The Transactions**

The Transactions consist of the Issuance of the Notes, receipt of shareholder contribution from entities owned by
TDR Capital (which may be pursuant to an equity investment or the Sponsor Subordinated Loan Agreement),
entering into the Second Lien Facility Agreement, the RCF Amendment Agreement and the Indenture in each
case on or prior to the Issue Date, as applicable, the entry into associated documentation including the Transaction
Security Documents, the use of proceeds of the various financing steps and any step or other matter incidental
thereto.

In connection with the Issuance, the Issuer has entered into a backstop agreement (the “Backstop Agreement”)
with certain holders of the Existing Notes, who together hold approximately 54% of the outstanding aggregate
principal amount of the Existing Notes across all three series of the Existing Notes (the “Backstop Parties”).
Pursuant to the Backstop Agreement, the Backstop Parties have agreed to participate in the Issuance and purchase
a portion of the Offered Notes, and/or backstop the remaining portion of the Offered Notes not otherwise
purchased by other parties, in each case on the certain pricing terms specified therein. In compensation for such
backstop arrangements, the Issuer has agreed to issue the Premium Sterling Notes to the Backstop Parties. In
addition, the Backstop Agreement also provides for certain cash compensation payable to the Backstop Parties.
The backstop provided by the Backstop Parties is subject to customary conditions, and may be terminated if the
Issuance has not completed on or prior to August 31, 2024 or such later date as may be agreed between the Issuer
and the majority Backstop Parties.

The Transactions present a significant overhaul of our capital structure, backed by a material contribution by our
sponsor, TDR Capital. Pursuant to the refinancing, our maturity runway in respect of our senior debt is extended
by five years and of our second lien debt by one and half years, with strong day one liquidity (consisting of
approximately £112 million of cash, and £150 million of credit facilities and £25 million of overdraft facilities
available to draw under the Revolving Facilities). Further, our cash debt service costs are eased given the
prepayment of the amortizing Unique A4 Notes and the elimination of cash interest payments in respect of the
Second Lien Facility. As a result, the Transactions are expected to improve our free cash flow generation and

10


-----

thereby support further investment in growth opportunities. In addition, the Transactions also preserve the scale
and benefit to the Stonegate Group from the portfolio of 1,034 Leased and Tenanted pubs, which, were transferred
to certain unrestricted subsidiaries of the Stonegate Group in connection with a limited recourse financing
transaction completed in January 2024. See “—Platinum Transactions.”

**Platinum Transactions**

On January 26, 2024, we completed a limited recourse financing of a portfolio of 1,034 Platinum Pubs, which was
structured as a sale to certain Unrestricted Subsidiaries of the Parent (the “Platinum Transactions”).

On or about December 20, 2023, we designated Stonegate Entity A Limited, a wholly owned subsidiary of the
Parent, together with its direct and indirect subsidiaries (the “Platinum Group”), as Unrestricted Subsidiaries,
among others, under the Existing Indenture, the Revolving Facilities Agreement and the Existing Second Lien
Facility Agreement. Thereafter, on January 26, 2024, the Stonegate Group completed the transfer of the Platinum
Pubs to the Platinum Group for an aggregate consideration of £810 million. The transfers comprised assets
transfers in the case of the free-of-tie pubs, and share transfers in respect of three property-owning special purpose
vehicles. Of the aggregate consideration of £810 million, £609 million was received by the Stonegate Group as
cash proceeds, funded pursuant to the Platinum Facilities incurred by the Platinum Group (as described below),
and Stonegate Group issued a promissory note for the remaining £201 million owed by Platinum Group(the
“Platinum Promissory Note”). The Platinum Promissory Note bears interest at a capitalized payment-in-kind
(PIK) rate of 14.00% and matures eight years from the closing of the Platinum Transaction.

The Platinum Pubs portfolio comprises 944 tied pubs and 90 free-of-tie pubs, held on a freehold basis, which
contributed an adjusted EBITDA of £78 million for the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024. See “Summary Historical
_and Pro Forma Financial and Other Information—Certain Non-IFRS Financial Information in relation to the_
_Stonegate Group.” The Platinum Pubs portfolio is predominantly weighted towards the South of England and_
generates the majority of its revenue from drink sales, with a mid-market focus and a strong bias towards wellpopulated, suburban locations. As part of the Platinum Transactions, the Parent has also entered into certain
agreements with Platinum Group on an arm’s length basis to provide the Platinum Pubs portfolio with certain
management and procurement services, which are also described below.

The Platinum Transactions followed a comprehensive and competitive process undertaken by us, and marked a
significant step in achieving our long-term balance sheet goals and facilitating deleveraging, while preserving
optionality and value upside. Pursuant to the Platinum Transactions, the Stonegate Group raised £609 million of
day-one cash proceeds, a significant portion of which is being utilized in connection with the Transactions, and
supported deleveraging of the Stonegate Group by virtue of the credit support afforded by the Platinum Promissory
Note. In addition, the Platinum Transactions enable us to continue to benefit from the contribution by the Platinum
Pubs portfolio to our scale, allowing us to retain strategic oversight and optionality for a future sale of the Platinum
Pubs portfolio in a value maximizing market environment and preserves value upside as well as efficiencies of
scale from the portfolio remaining within the Group.

**_Services Agreement_**

Pursuant to a services agreement entered between the Parent and the relevant Platinum Group entities (the
“Services Agreement”), the Parent provides, in exchange for specified fees, certain services, including but not
limited to operational support, account management, inspection and repairs, insurance, license management,
letting, rent reviews and services in relation to sales of pubs owned by the Platinum Group. In addition, the Parent
also provides services in relation to identifying and evaluating capital expenditure projects that are suitable for
each Platinum Group entity, in accordance with certain specified terms and conditions. In lieu of the services
provided by the Parent under the Services Agreement, the Platinum Group pays asset management fees of £6,000
annually per tied pub and £3,000 per free-of-tie pub, adjusted annually for changes in the consumer price index.

The Parent is to provide services to pubs owned by the Platinum Group in the same manner as it would to pubs
prior to the Platinum Transactions or to its other Leased and Tenanted pubs, whichever standard is higher. In
discharging its duties as manager, the Parent is required to exercise the level of professional skill, diligence and
care as would reasonably be expected from an experienced manager of pubs of like scale and quality and to act in
good faith. The Parent may engage third party subcontractors or advisers to provide certain services in a manner
consistent with past practice. Any costs in connection therewith will be covered by the asset management fees the
Parent receives. To the extent that the Parent engages any advisor to carry out certain technical, specialist or
fulfillment services, the costs of such services will be in addition to the asset management fees and charged to the

11


-----

applicable pubs, subject to a cap. The Parent also provides certain marketing and promotion support to publicans
upon request. Any costs of such services and any concession received by the Parent is passed on to the applicable
publicans. The Services Agreement also provides for certain marketing and promotional expenses payable
Platinum Group to the Parent, subject to an annual cap per pub.

The Services Agreement will remain in effect until terminated by (i) the Platinum Group or the lender agent under
the Platinum Facilities upon customary grounds for termination or (2) by the Parent with at least six-months’
notice, provided that the Platinum Group and the lender agent consent to such termination and that a substitute
manager, as approved by the lender agent, is appointed prior to termination.

**_Procurement Agreement_**

The Parent also entered into, in its capacity as supplier, a certain procurement agreement (“the **Procurement**
**Agreement”) with the Platinum Group, pursuant to which the Parent sources drink products for purchase by**
publicans of the Platinum Pubs at cost, net of any rebates, refunds or discounts the Parent may receive. Any
services in connection with procurement, including logistics, dispensing, distribution and any other activities
reasonable incidental to the supply of drink products is also provided at cost. The Parent also procures that its
third-party suppliers provide such equipment and technical sales support services as may be reasonably requested
by the publicans free of charge.

Under the Procurement Agreement, the Parent is required to use reasonable efforts to ensure that sufficient drink
products are in stock so as to fulfil any orders placed by publicans of Platinum Pubs. The Parent is also required
to notify the Platinum Group of any material changes to the terms of third-party supplier contracts that will
materially impact the supply of drink products to pubs owned by the Platinum Group. As a supplier, the Parent is
to provide procurement services to Platinum Pubs in the same manner as it would to pubs prior to the Platinum
Transactions or to in respect of its other current Leased and Tenanted pubs, whichever standard is higher. In
discharging its duties as supplier, the Parent is required to exercise the level of professional skill, diligence and
care as would reasonably be expected from an experienced supplier to pubs of like scale and quality and to act in
good faith at all times.

The Parent may engage third party subcontractors to provide certain services necessary to ensure the supply of
products in a manner consistent with past practice. Any costs of subcontracting in respect of providing
procurement services will be covered by the management fees the Parent receives under the Services Agreement.
Any costs of subcontracting pursuant to a request from the Platinum Group for services not in the ordinary course
will be in addition to the management fees and charged to the applicable Platinum Group entity.

The Procurement Agreement will remain in effect until terminated by (i) the Platinum Group or the lender agent
under the Platinum Facilities upon customary grounds for termination or (2) by the Parent with at least six-months’
notice, provided that the Platinum Group and the lender agent consent to such termination and that a substitute
supplier, as approved by the lender agent, is appointed prior to termination.

**_Platinum Facilities_**

To partially fund the cash consideration in connection with the purchase of the Platinum Pubs, on December 20,
2023, certain Platinum Group entities entered into English-law governed secured whole-business loan agreements,
consisting of a senior facility agreement (the “Platinum **SFA”) and a mezzanine facility agreement (the**
“Platinum **MFA” and, together with the Platinum SFA, the “Platinum Facilities”). The Platinum Facilities were**
fully drawn by the Platinum Group on or about the date of completion of the Platinum Transactions, which was
January 26, 2024.

The Platinum SFA provides for a term loan credit facility in the amount of £438,000,000. Loans under the
Platinum SFA initially bear interest rate equal to the 3-month SONIA rate, subject to a floor of 2.5%, plus a margin
of 5.00% per annum. The Platinum MFA provides for a term loan credit facility in the amount of £200,000,000.
Loans under the Platinum MFA initially bear interest rate equal to the 3-month SONIA rate, subject to a floor of
2.5%, plus a margin of 9.3065% per annum. The Platinum Facilities mature on the third anniversary of utilization
date, which is January 26, 2027, subject to two one-year extension options exercisable at the borrower’s discretion.
Subject to certain conditions, the Platinum Facilities allow for voluntary prepayments, and in addition, require the
application of certain proceeds towards the mandatory prepayment, for instance if the Platinum Group obligors
receive proceeds from permitted property disposals.

12


-----

The Platinum Facilities are each guaranteed by certain Platinum Group entities and are secured pursuant to English
law governed security agreements granting security over all assets of relevant Platinum Group entities. The lenders
under the Platinum Facilities do not have any recourse to the Stonegate Group. The Platinum Facilities rank senior
to the Platinum Promissory Note.

The Platinum Facilities require the Platinum Group obligor entities to observe certain covenants, including
covenants relating to incurrence of financial indebtedness, incurrence of guarantee or indemnity, shareholder
distributions, issuance of shares and business combination. The Platinum Facilities also contain an information
covenant and a financial covenant. In addition, the Platinum Facilities prescribe certain operational controls on
the Platinum Group, including (but not limited to) limitations relating to capital expenditures, letting activities,
property title split, disposal of certain assets and properties and reorganization.

of pubs from Mitchells & Butlers. We began trading operations in November 2010 after the acquisition of pubs
from Mitchells & Butlers was completed. The registered office of the Company is at the offices of Conyers Trust
Company (Cayman) Limited, Cricket Square, Hutchins Drive, PO Box 2681, Grand Cayman KY1-1111, Cayman
Islands and its telephone number at that address is +1 345 949 1040.

Stonegate Pub Company Financing 2019 plc (the “Issuer”) was incorporated on July 9, 2019 as a public limited
company under the laws of England and Wales in connection with the financing of the Ei Acquisition. The Issuer
is a wholly-owned finance subsidiary of the Parent. The Issuer is organized as a special purpose finance subsidiary
to facilitate the offering of debt securities with no business operations or material assets, other than its rights under
the various intercompany loans made to other Group entities in relation to the proceeds of financings from time
to time. The registered office of the Issuer is 3 Monkspath Hall Road, Shirley, Solihull, West Midlands, B90 4SJ,
United Kingdom and its telephone number at that address is +44 (0) 121 272 5000.

**About TDR Capital**

TDR is a leading private equity firm with over €15 billion of assets under management and typically invests in
strong European companies that are leaders in their markets. TDR has a 22-year track record of working
collaboratively with portfolio company management teams to deliver on a shared vision for growth and value
creation, leveraging its investment, operational and data science expertise. TDR not only invests capital in
portfolio companies, but also provides expert team resources to help bring about sustainable, positive and
transformational change within its businesses.

“Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

**Additional Amounts ......................** Any payments made by the Issuer, the Successor Company (as defined
herein) or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without
withholding or deduction for or on account of taxes unless required by
law. If the Issuer, the Successor Company or the Guarantors are required
by law to withhold or deduct amounts for or on account of tax imposed
by the UK (or certain other relevant taxing jurisdictions) with respect to
a payment to the holders of the Notes, the Issuer, the Successor
Company or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to certain exceptions,
pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received
by the holders of the Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less
than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the
withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Additional
_Amounts.”_


**Redemption for Taxation**
**Reasons ...........................................**


In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may
redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at a redemption price of
100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any,
and additional amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See
“Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”


**Further issuance of Notes .............** Pursuant to the terms of the Indenture, the Issuer will be permitted to
issue additional Notes. Additional Notes shall be treated, along with all
other notes issued under the Indenture, as a single class for the purposes
of the Indenture with respect to waivers, amendments and all other
matters which are not specifically distinguished for such series.

For all purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes, additional
Notes shall be deemed to form one series with any notes previously
issued under the Indenture if they have terms substantially identical in
all material respects to such other notes. In the event that any additional
Notes issued after the date hereof and sold pursuant to Rule 144A are
not fungible with any notes previously issued under the Indenture for
U.S. federal income tax purposes, such non-fungible additional Notes
shall be issued with a separate ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other
securities identification number, as applicable, so that they are
distinguishable from such previously issued notes under the Indenture.
Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may
be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities
identification number as the applicable series of notes previously issued
under the Indenture without being fungible with such series of notes for

20


-----

U.S. federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined
in “Tax Considerations— _Certain U.S. Federal Income Taxation_
_Considerations”) considering the purchase of Notes sold pursuant to_
Regulation S, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the
particular U.S. federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase,
ownership and disposition of such Notes, including with respect to the
potential issuance of additional Notes that are not fungible with the
applicable series of initial notes issued under the Indenture for U.S.
federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of
being separately identified.

**Change of Control .........................** Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control,
the Issuer may be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes
at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the principal amount
redeemed on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest, if
any, to the date of purchase. See “Description of the Notes—Change of
_Control.” However, a change of control will not be deemed to have_
occurred if certain consolidated leverage ratios are not exceeded in
connection with such an event. See “Description of the Notes—Change
_of Control.”_

**Certain Covenants .........................** The Indenture relating to the Notes, among other things, will restrict the
ability of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries to:

                 - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness;

                 - pay dividends or make other distributions or purchase or
redeem our stock;

                 - make investments or other restricted payments;

                 - enter into agreements that restrict our restricted subsidiaries’
ability to pay dividends;

                 - transfer or sell assets;

                 - engage in transactions with affiliates;

                 - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness;

                 - impair security interests; and

                 - merge or consolidate with or into another company.

Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and
qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.”

**Transfer Restrictions .....................** We have not registered the Notes or the Note Guarantees under the
Securities Act. You may only offer or sell the Notes in transactions that
are exempt from, or not subject to, the registration requirements of the
Securities Act, or pursuant to an effective registration statement. See
“Transfer Restrictions.” We have not agreed to, or otherwise
undertaken, to register the Notes under the Securities Act.

**No Prior Market ............................** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no
established trading market. Although certain of the Initial Purchasers
have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are
not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any
time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active
trading market will develop for the Notes.

21


-----

**Listing .............................................** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and
permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange.
There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official
List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be
granted or that such listing will be maintained.

**Use of Proceeds ..............................** We intend to use the proceeds from the Notes, the Second Lien Facility
and shareholder contribution, along with cash on balance sheet to (i)
redeem any and all outstanding aggregate principal amount of the
Existing Notes, (ii) redeem any and all outstanding aggregate principal
amount of the Class A Unique Notes, (iii) part-prepay borrowings under
the Revolving Facilities, (iv) discharge our liabilities under the Existing
Second Lien Facility Agreement in full and (v) pay certain costs, fees
and expenses in connection with the Transactions. See “Use of
_Proceeds.”_

**Governing Law ..............................** The Indenture and the Note Guarantees will be, governed by the laws
of the State of New York. The Revolving Facilities Agreement, the
Second Lien Facility Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement are
governed by English law. The Security Documents are governed by
English law or the laws of the Cayman Islands, as applicable.
