_Drink and food costs_

Our results are affected by the cost of supplies purchased from third parties. While a majority of our supply chain
is UK based, we also seek to capitalize on opportunities to mitigate, where possible, foreign supply chain costs by
switching to less expensive geographies. We purchase beer and other drink products from various suppliers. Our
six leading drink suppliers during the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024 were Heineken UK, Molson Coors (UK),
Matthew Clark Wholesale Limited, Diageo, Carlsberg and LWC Drinks. Our gross margins derived from beer
and other drink products is affected by changes in the wholesale prices at which they are bought from brewers
and suppliers and the corresponding changes in prices at which they are sold on to customers. Our gross margin
for drinks sales can also be impacted by duty escalators that may be applied by the government in the UK with
respect to alcoholic drinks. See “Industry.” Our gross margin for food sales is affected by the changes in prices at
which food is bought, the corresponding changes in wholesale prices at which they are sold on to customers and
the impact of our menu changes. As a result of inflation and current macro-economic conditions in the UK
(including the impact of Brexit) and elsewhere, there has been a general increase in wholesale prices of beer and
other drink products, as well as food. However, our drink and food costs remained stable, increasing only by a
non-meaningful percentage during the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024 as compared to the 28 weeks ended April 9,
2023.

We rely on key suppliers and distributors to ensure there is a continuous supply of both food, drink and other
products to our Managed pubs and its publicans. We are exposed to the risk of failure by these suppliers to deliver
in the required time frames or to the standards expected. We have mitigated supply risks as much as possible by
expanding the number of our key suppliers for food and drink and have established a disaster recovery and
business continuity plan to mitigate such risks.

_Employment Costs_

Employment costs constituted 26.7% of our operating costs for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, of which
53.5% constituted the cost of wages (which are a variable cost to us) and the remaining 46.5% constituted the cost
of salaries (which are a fixed cost to us). In addition, employment costs constituted 25.9% of our operating costs
for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, of which 53.4% constituted the cost of wages and the remaining 47.8%
constituted the cost of salaries.

Minimum wage legislation, which is also driven by macro-economic conditions and inflation, largely establishes
our base compensation levels. In April 2016, the UK government announced the introduction of a National Living
Wage, which replaced the national minimum wage for all working people aged 23 and over in the UK. The
National Minimum Wage remained in place for all working people under the age of 22 who are at least school
leaving age in the UK. In April 2021, the National Minimum Wage for people from school leaving age in the UK
to 18 was increased to £4.62 per hour. At the same time, the National Minimum Wage for people aged 18 to 20
and for people aged 21 to 22 was increased to £6.56 per hour and £8.36 per hour, respectively, while the National
Living Wage for people aged 23 and over was increased to £8.91 per hour. In April 2022, the National Minimum
Wage for people from school leaving age in the UK to 18 was increased to £4.81 per hour. At the same time, the
National Minimum Wage for people aged 18 to 20 and for people aged 21 to 22 was increased to £6.83 per hour
and £9.18 per hour, respectively, while the National Living Wage for people aged 23 and over was increased to
£9.50 per hour. In April 2023, the National Minimum Wage for people from school leaving age in the UK to 18
was increased to £5.28 per hour. At the same time, the National Minimum Wage for people aged 18 to 20 and for
people aged 21 to 22 was increased to £7.49 per hour and £10.18 per hour, respectively, while the National Living
Wage for people aged 23 and over was increased to £10.42 per hour. In April 2024, in the UK, the National

77


-----

Minimum Wage was increased to £6.40 per hour for people aged under 18, to £8.60 per hour for people aged 18
to 20, and to £11.44 per hour for people aged 21 and over.

While we closely monitor staffing levels, especially in our Managed Pubs business to ensure efficiency of staff
rostering and to effectively manage our employment costs, a continued increase in such costs, whether due to
macro-economic environment, market conditions or increases in mandatory minimum wages or benefits, can have
a material impact on our results of operations. Increases in employee turnover can also result in increased
recruiting expenses and reduced efficiency through lost management time. During the 28 weeks ended April 7,
2024, our employment costs increased by 3.5% as compared to the prior period, primarily due to increases in the
National Living Wage and salary increases driven by macro-economic conditions and inflation and offer
potentially by a smaller estate. In this context, we have implemented an initiative to optimize organizational
functions across our operations and reduce headcount, which we estimate will result in an annual cost savings of
£8 million. A majority of the identified headcount reductions have been completed and we expect remaining
reductions to be completed during the course of financial year 2024. Our cost savings estimate include severance
and other related costs that we expect to incur.

Employment costs includes within it labor costs. For the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks
ended April 7, 2024, our labor costs, which represents our aggregate site labor costs only (and is a financial metric
commonly used in our industry) were 19.4% and 19.6%, respectively, of revenue. We believe that we have the
ability to manage our fixed and variable labor costs at different levels of sales volumes if it is required.

_Other costs_

With respect to our property portfolio as of April 7, 2024, the majority of our leases have less than five-year rent
review cycles. We believe that relatively weak commercial rental markets outside of London give us a strong
negotiating position in those markets. Our capital investment in the pubs we rent and efforts to extend lease terms
have also historically helped us negotiate rent concessions from our landlords. For the period our pubs were
temporarily closed due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we entered into arrangements with landlords to defer rent
payments during the period of closure.

We believe that we have the ability to manage our managed pub site costs at different levels of sales volumes if it
is required; however, we have less flexibility to manage our operating lease rental expense, site overhead costs
and central overhead costs at different levels of sales volumes. Costs related to our business rates are affected by
government policies in effect from time to time. Our site costs (including costs associated with trading, energy
and utilities, door, live entertainment, consumables, promotions, staff expenses, Sky TV, house repairs, refuse and
other site operating costs) were £216 million and £133 million for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and
the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively. Our site costs, increased by 7.8% during the 28 weeks ended April
7, 2024 as compared to the prior period, primarily due to the increase in energy and utility costs at our Managed
and Operator-run pubs. As a result of the war in Ukraine in February 2022, the global energy market has seen
significant disruption in recent periods and a substantial increase in business and domestic energy prices. In
response, among other initiatives, the UK government announced discounts on business energy unit rates
applicable from October 1, 2022 to March 31, 2023. Effective April 1, 2023, the UK government announced a
new scheme for businesses with a reduced level of discount to energy rates available if the wholesale energy prices
are above a certain price threshold. The UK government energy discount scheme lapsed on March 31, 2024.
Although we have benefited from these schemes, as a result of drop in energy prices during summer of 2023, we
are currently not utilizing this scheme. In addition, on the back of recent drop in energy prices, we have sought to
manage our exposure to energy costs by hedging almost 100% and 75% of our expected electricity usage for
summer and winter 2024 and 98% and 78% of our expected gas usage for summer and winter 2024.

Our site overhead costs (including bonuses, insurance premium, building repairs, other overhead costs and other
operating income) were £105 million and £38 million for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28
weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively. Our central overhead costs, covering head office and other pub support
costs, were £117 million and £76 million for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended
April 7, 2024, respectively. Our business rate payments were £46 million and £23 million for the 52 weeks ended
September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively.

In addition, we aim to control our operating costs through the efficient use of our utilities, such as lighting and
waste management, and we evaluate the terms of our contracts with our utility providers on an on-going basis.

**_Focused Investment Program and Continued Operating Efficiency Improvements_**

We have a focused investment program and take a disciplined approach to investment appraisal. We identify
priority investments through biannual estate reviews, and approve each project at multiple levels, before it can
finally be approved at our senior management meetings. Proposed schemes are reviewed at the Managing Director
executive committee chaired by our managing directors and the operations board chaired by our CEO before being
authorized at our senior management meetings chaired by our chairman. After the COVID-19 closure period,
beginning June 21, 2021 through April 7, 2024, we have refurbished approximately 120 Managed or Operatorrun pubs and converted 185 pubs from our Leased and Tenanted estate. Our investments made over the last two
years are also presented at each senior management meeting for post-investment review.

We seek to actively invest in our estate, with a particular focus on executing opportunities with relatively high
return on investment. We periodically carry out a detailed review and identify opportunities to convert pubs in
each of our Leased and Tenanted, Managed and Operator-run formats to the other formats, generally with a view
to potentially uplift EBITDA per pub and increase profitability. Further to the Ei Acquisition, we have
implemented a program to convert select Leased and Tenanted pubs to Craft Union pubs and to our other Managed
pub formats. In particular, we believe that a significant opportunity for value creation exists in the Craft Union
community pubs model (quasi-managed/franchised platform), as these pubs are run by self-employed operators
who receive a fixed percentage of revenue generated in these pubs, thereby making site earnings less volatile. In
addition, we have also selectively converted certain Managed pubs into Operator-run pubs, and particularly to
manage our operating costs while earning revenue as dry rent and/or wet rent, into Leased and Tenanted pubs.
During the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, we converted 15 Leased and Tenanted pubs to Managed pubs,
63 Leased and Tenanted pubs into Operator-run pubs, 23 Managed pubs to Operator-run pubs and 29 Managed
pubs to Leased and Tenanted Pubs. In addition, during this period, we also converted three Operator-run pubs to
Leased and Tenanted pubs. During the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, we converted 1 Leased and Tenanted pub
to a Managed pub, 16 Leased and Tenanted pubs into Operator-run pubs, 24 Managed pubs to Operator-run pubs,
17 Managed pubs to Leased and Tenanted pubs and 8 Operator-run pubs to Leased and Tenanted pubs. We believe
that our ability to successfully identify ideal trading formats for the pubs we acquire, and to integrate and/or
convert these pubs into those formats, has allowed us to achieve strong like for like revenue growth.

During the periods impacted by COVID-19 pandemic and our efforts at the time to manage cash outflows and
preserve and build liquidity, our ability to make investments in our estate, including investments made to convert
Leased and Tenanted pubs from Ei Group’s estate to our Managed Pubs formats or to the Craft Union format, was
limited. Following the removal of the COVID-19 restrictions and the return to a steady state of business, we
resumed actively investing in our estate. In particular, for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, the Group
spent £64 million on Investment Capital Expenditure, as compared to £55 million during the 52 weeks ended
September 25, 2022 and £18 million during the 52 weeks ended September 26, 2021.

Furthermore, in light of the increase in our operating costs in recent periods, we have begun implementing a
program to selectively convert certain Managed pubs into Leased and Tenanted pubs or Operator-run pubs. We
believe that the selected pubs are more suitable for operations under the Leased and Tenanted model, and the
conversion will allow us to better rationalize our operating cost, while earning revenue from these pubs as dry
rent and/or wet rent. We intend to continue to implement these conversions during the course of financial year
2024.

**_Ability to Assist Pub Partners and Utilize Learnings from our Managed Pubs Segment_**

We have historically provided Pub Partners with a broad range of services to help them increase sales and reduce
costs, and to operate their pubs efficiently and effectively. In particular, from the operation of our Managed Pubs,
we are able to provide additional insight, experience and best practices, all of which help us further enhance the
support that can be provided to Pub Partners. We also assist Pub Partners during periods of economic challenge
in order to help prevent business failures, including providing direct financial assistance. For instance, in light of
and during the COVID-19 pandemic, we had extended an overall support package to our Pub Partners consisting
of rent credits, trade credits, concessions on tie release fees and fixtures and fittings. The extent of business failures
and the need to provide support to publicans from time to time tends to affect income from our Leased and
Tenanted pubs. For example, if Pub Partners experience low sales volumes for extended periods of time, they may
not be able to pay rent at the levels agreed or at all, which could reduce our rental income.

79

**_Regulation_**

Our pubs are subject to laws and regulations that affect their operations, including in relation to employment,
minimum wages, alcoholic drinks control, late-night levies, drink-driving, pub licensing, leisure (gaming)
machines, competition, health and safety, sanitation, data protection and access for the disabled. See “Industry”
and “Business.”

We are subject to the Working Time Regulations in the UK. As we employ a large number of our staff at the
minimum wage, increases in the minimum wage may result in increases in our labor costs and, to the extent we
are not able to pass through these labor cost increases to our customers, we may experience an adverse impact on
our gross margins. See “—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—Operating Costs Control—
_Employee Costs.”_

In addition, in relation to a majority of our Leased and Tenanted pubs, we are subject to the Pubs Code, introduced
by the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015, which came into effect on July 21, 2016. The Pubs
Code regulates the relationship between tied pub tenants and the large pub-owning businesses that rent pubs to
tenants and sell them tied products, and establishes a new independent Pubs Code adjudicator to enforce the code.
The Pubs Code provides tied publicans with a right, under certain circumstances, to replace their existing freelynegotiated tied agreements with a new free-of-tie MRO arrangement, which could have an impact on our income
from publican partnership pubs.

Licensing authorities in the UK are authorized to impose a late-night levy on late-opening alcohol suppliers. Many
of our pubs are open late and some are subject to these late-night levies. To the extent that individual licensing
authorities decide to implement late-night levies or the government decides to increase the scope of these powers,
we could experience an increase in our operating costs.

Furthermore, we are subject to certain disclosure requirements such as those provided under the Calorie Labelling
(Out of Home sector) (England) Regulations 2021 requiring businesses with more than 250 employees to display
calorie information on non-packaged food and soft drink menus. In addition, Martyn’s Law (currently expected
to be adopted as law in the coming months) puts premises owners under a duty to consider the threat from terrorism
and implement proportionate mitigating measures and its implementation could require us to undertake additional
expansion and/or reconfiguration in our premises. Compliance with these laws and regulations impose costs and
administrative burdens on us, as our managers are required to devote significant amounts of their time to managing
and ensuring compliance with these requirements, which reduces the time they are able to dedicate to the running
of the business. For risks related to changes in regulations to which we are subject or the introduction of new
regulations to which we may become subject, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—Changes in
_regulations to which we are subject or the introduction of new regulations to which we may become subject could_
_have a negative effect on our business.”_

**_Seasonal Effects_**

Attendance levels at our pubs are affected by the weather and by the timing of major sporting events. Persistent
rain, snow or other inclement weather, especially during the summer months or over our peak trading periods such
as the Christmas period, Easter, bank holidays and end-of-the-month salary weekends, or weekends in general,
can have a negative effect on our revenue. Inclement weather during major sporting events can also affect our
revenue due to lower footfall resulting from poor weather conditions. The absence of major sporting events, or
the poor performance of a British team, could have a negative impact on our results of operations. In particular,
the cancellation or postponement of sporting events (or the holding of sporting events behind closed doors or with
a limited number of spectators (for instance, during the period impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic), could lead
to lower footfall in our pubs, and thereby a decline in our revenue. The seasonality of the pub industry results in
variable demand and, consequently, our revenue and operating results tend to fluctuate from period to period.

**Segment Reporting**

Further to the acquisition of Ei Group (which we completed on March 3, 2020) and the integration of the Ei Group
business segments with our business, including the conversion of pubs into different operating models and formats
so as to enhance value creation and profitability, we introduced the following reportable segments from the period
commencing on July 4, 2021:

- _Leased and Tenanted, in which we have no direct involvement in the operations and which consists of_
(i) Pub Partnerships, covering rental income and revenue from supply of drinks and gaming machines

80


-----

from our tied Pub Partners and (ii) commercial properties, covering rental income from our untied
commercial properties;

- _Managed Pubs, in which we manage the site fully, taking on full operational risk and in return receiving_
the full retail margin, and which consists of (i) the managed pubs operated by us and (ii) managed
investments operated pursuant to certain joint ventures entered into by us with experienced retail
partners; and

- _Operator-run, in which we contract with a third party operator to manage the day-to-day operations of_
the site, receiving a turnover-based fee. All labor costs are borne by the third party, but all other costs are
borne by us, and we have access to the full retail margin covering revenue from the sale of food, drink,
accommodation and gaming machine income. This segment consists of our Craft Union format.

Note 2 of our financial statements as of and for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024 and the 52 weeks ended
September 24, 2023 included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum presents revenue, Group Pre-adjusted
EBITDA and certain other metrics by reporting segment. We eliminate intersegment revenues and costs upon
consolidation and the segmental note is presented net of these eliminations.

All of our revenue is generated in the UK and is not further segmented based on location. Therefore, no
geographical segmental analysis has been provided.

**Description of Key Income Statement Line Items**

**_Revenue_**

Our revenue is mainly derived from the sale of food and drinks to third parties, after deducting discounts and
VAT. It also includes revenue derived from admission, accommodation and machine (gaming), and is recognized
at the point of sale. In addition, it includes rent revenue, which is recognized on a straight line basis for the term
of the lease based on the contractual terms of the lease agreements.

**_Other Income_**

Other income includes monies received in the form of government grants and furlough income and are recorded
in the income statement in the same periods during which the related expenses were incurred.

**_Operating Costs before Depreciation & Amortization_**

Our operating costs before depreciation and amortization represent our drink and food costs, employment costs
and other costs. For instance,

- our drink and food costs represented 36.3% of our operating costs before depreciation and amortization
for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and 35.5% for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, and in
each case, primarily comprised the costs associated with the supply of our food and drinks;

- our employment costs represented 26.7% of our operating costs before depreciation and amortization for
the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and 25.9% for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, and in each
case primarily comprised salaries and wages to our staff and management; and

- our other costs represented 37.0% of our operating costs before depreciation and amortization for the 52
weeks ended September 24, 2023 and 38.6% for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, and in each case
primarily comprised, energy and utilities costs, door costs (i.e., costs associated with entrance security at
some of our pubs), live entertainment costs, live sport subscription costs (such as the cost of subscriptions
to Sky TV), repair and maintenance costs, business rates, insurance costs, marketing costs and IT system
costs.

81


-----

**_EBITDA_**

EBITDA represents operating profit / (loss) before depreciation, amortization, impairment, revaluation and profit
on sale of non-current assets.

**_Depreciation, Amortization, Impairment and Revaluation_**

Depreciation relates to the depreciation and impairment of our property, plant and equipment over their useful
lives. Amortization relates to the amortization and impairment of certain of our intangible assets over their useful
lives. Goodwill arising on consolidation in respect of acquisitions is capitalized and is tested annually for
impairment.

**_Profit/(Loss) on Sale of Non-Current Assets_**

Profit/(loss) on sale of non-current assets represents the difference between the proceeds received from the sale
of a site and its book value. For the 52 weeks ended September 25, 2022 and the 52 weeks ended September 24,
2023, this line item also includes write-offs related to certain tangible fixed assets at certain sites that are no longer
in use due to capital investments made at these sites.

**_Finance Income_**

Our finance income represents interest receivable on loans extended to certain members of our management as
well as interest that accrued on our overnight bank deposits, which we recognize as it accrues using the effective
interest method.

**_Finance Costs_**

Our finance costs include interest on bank loans, notes, the loans made to certain members of our management,
certain pension charges related to the carrying value of our pension liability to its fair value, amortization of debt
issue costs and certain other interest expenses.

**_Movement in Fair Value of Swaps_**

Movement in fair value of swaps represents the movement on the fair value of the interest rate and currency swaps
between balance sheet dates.

**_UK Income Tax Credit/(Charge)_**

The charge for taxation is based on the profit or loss for the period and takes into account taxation deferred because
of timing differences between the treatment of certain items for taxation and accounting purposes. Deferred tax is
recognized, without discounting, in respect of all timing differences between the treatment of certain items for
taxation and accounting purposes which have arisen but not been reversed by the balance sheet date, except as
otherwise required by International Accounting Standard 12.

An increase of corporation tax in the UK to 25% (effective from April 1, 2023) was announced by the UK
government in the March 2021 budget and substantively enacted in the prior year to adjust deferred tax balances
to the 25% tax rate.

**_Profit/(Loss) for the Period_**

Profit/(loss) for the period represents the result of the consolidated income statement after provision for taxation.

**Key Operating Metrics of Stonegate Group**

Our like to like metrics, in particular, Stonegate Group Managed Revenue Growth (Like for Like), Stonegate
Group Operator-run Revenue Growth (Like for Like) and Stonegate Group L&T Revenue Growth (Like for Like),
are some of the key operating metrics used to evaluate our performance. Various factors affect our like for like
metrics, including:

- the prevailing economic climate and trends, including the impact of inflation and high interest rate;

89


-----

- customer preferences and our ability to anticipate and respond effectively to trends and customer
preferences;

- changes in the competitive environment;

- the level of our capital investment in our pubs;

- changes in our food and drink mix and pricing;

- the number and mix of pubs included in the calculation;

- health emergencies, such as the COVID-19 pandemic;

- management of our pubs and the level of customer service that we provide; and

- our ability to source and distribute food and drink products efficiently.

We present these like-for-like metrics, as we believe they enable discussion on comparative operating performance
of our pubs in each of our three segments. In addition, we present them for Stonegate Group only as the Notes
shall be guaranteed by Stonegate Group entities and the restrictive covenants in the Indenture, the Revolving
Facilities Agreement apply to Stonegate Group only. We believe these Stonegate Group metrics enhance the
investor’s understanding of Stonegate Group and its ability to fund our ongoing operations, make capital
expenditures and meet and service its obligations. These Stonegate Group metrics have not been and will not be
audited or reviewed in accordance with any generally accepted auditing standards. Such figures may not have
been prepared on the same basis as the Group figures and therefore investors should not place undue reliance on
such figures.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

**_Liquidity_**

We have significant debt service obligations. As of April 7, 2024, after giving effect to the Transactions (including
the issuance of the Notes, and the application of the proceeds therefrom, as applicable), Stonegate Group would
have had total adjusted third-party debt of £2,521 million (excluding a lease liability of £658 million as of April
7, 2024, calculated in accordance with IFRS 16). Following the completion of the Transactions, our Revolving
Facilities are expected to be drawn in an amount of £98 million, and we would have £150 million of credit facilities
and £25 million of overdraft facilities available to draw under the Revolving Facilities Agreement (subject to our
continued compliance with the covenants therein, including the financial covenant). See also “Capitalization” and
“Description of Other Indebtedness.”

The Revolving Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Facility Agreement contain, and the Indenture governing
the Notes and the Sponsor Subordinated Loan Agreement (if entered into) will contain, covenants significantly
restricting our ability to, among other things:

- incur or guarantee additional indebtedness and issue certain preferred stock;

- create or incur certain liens;

- make certain payments, including dividends or other distributions, with respect to the shares of the
Parent;

- prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity;

- make certain investments;

- create encumbrances or restrictions on the payment of dividends or other distributions, loans or advances
to and on the transfer of assets to the Parent or its restricted subsidiaries;

- sell, lease or transfer certain assets including stock of restricted subsidiaries;

- engage in certain transactions with affiliates;

- enter into unrelated businesses or engage in prohibited activities;

- consolidate or merge with other entities;

- impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes; and

- amend certain documents.

Each of the covenants is subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications. These covenants could
limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs.

We depend upon our operations to generate strong cash flows to support our operating activities, supply capital
to finance our operations and growth, make capital expenditure and manage our debt levels. As a result, our
principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is our operating cash flow. Our ability to generate cash depends
on our future operating performance, which in turn depends on general economic, financial, industry and other
factors, many of which are beyond our control, as well as the other factors discussed in “Risk Factors.” In addition,
we have access to the Revolving Facilities to service our working capital and general corporate needs. The
availability of this facility is dependent upon conditions, including compliance with financial covenants relating
to our consolidated leverage ratio and other covenants as described further under “Description of Other
_Indebtedness—Revolving Facilities Agreement.” Although we believe that our expected cash flows from_

91


-----

operations, together with available borrowings, will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service
needs, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations or that future
debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due,
including the Notes, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

We believe that the potential risks to our liquidity include:

- increase in our operating costs, including drink and food costs, employment costs (such as cost of wages
and labor costs) and other costs such as energy and utility costs, due to inflation and other macroeconomic conditions;

- a reduction in operating cash flows due to a lowering of net income from our operations, which could be
due to downturns in our performance or the industry or the UK economy as a whole;

- exposure to increased interest rates and, more generally, financing costs in relation to that portion of our
borrowings which bears interest at a variable rate;

- inability to access capital;

- adverse working capital developments;

- a reduction in operating cash flows due to prolonged periods of closure or restrictions in the operations
of our pubs due to COVID-19 or other health emergencies; and

- any need to fund higher than anticipated capital expenditures.

If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources (including borrowings under our Revolving
Facilities) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced
to:

- reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditure;

- reduce or delay our planned acquisitions;

- sell assets;

- obtain additional debt or equity capital; or

- restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity.

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on
satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our debt, after giving effect to the Transactions, limit our
ability to pursue any of these alternatives, as may the terms of any future debt. We anticipate that our high leverage
will continue for the foreseeable future. Our high level of debt may have important negative consequences for
you. For more information, see the sections entitled “Risk Factors,” “Description of Other Indebtedness” and
“Description of the Notes.”

**_Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities_**

Our net cash flow from operating activities increased by £57 million, from a net cash inflow of £181 million for
the 28 weeks ended April 9, 2023 to a net cash inflow of £238 million for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024. This
increase was primarily driven by improvements in trading across both our Leased and Tenanted and Operator-run
segments more than offsetting a decline in trade in our Managed Pubs segment, particularly post-Christmas.

Our net cash flow from operating activities increased by £20 million, from a net cash inflow of £402 million for
the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2022 to a net cash inflow of £422 million for the 52 weeks ended September 24,
2023. This increase was primarily driven by the pay down by us of certain overdue items, most notably rents, tax
and professional fees, which related to previous periods when our pubs had remained closed due to the impact of
the COVID-19 pandemic and had been deferred and thus negatively impacted cash flows in the 52 weeks ended
September 25, 2022.

Our net cash flow from operating activities increased by £216 million, from a net cash inflow of £186 million for
the 52 weeks ended September 26, 2021 to a net cash inflow of £402 million for the 52 weeks ended September 25,
2022. This increase was primarily due to improved trading performance at our pubs and higher cash generation
during the 52 weeks ended September 25, 2022, as compared to 52 weeks ended September 26, 2021, which was

**Financial Risk Management**

Our board of directors regularly reviews our financial requirements and the risks associated with them. We have
summarized the principal risks arising from our current financial instruments below. See also Note 23 of our
consolidated financial statements as of and for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, included elsewhere in
this Offering Memorandum.

**_Interest Rate Risk_**

We finance our operations through a combination of trading cash flows, bank borrowings and longer term notes.
Borrowings under our Revolving Facilities Agreement, Second Lien Facility Agreement and Euro Notes will bear,
floating rates of interest. We seek to minimize our cost of borrowings and reduce the impact of interest rate
fluctuations, including through the entry into interest rate hedging agreements. For additional information on these
activities, see “—Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements.”

**_Liquidity Risk_**

We seek to manage financial risk to ensure sufficient liquidity is available to meet our foreseeable needs. We
monitor the maturity of our financial liabilities to avoid the risk of shortage of funds and also place surplus funds
on deposit so that they are available at short notice. See “—Liquidity and Capital Resources.”

**_Currency Risk_**

All of our revenue and the majority of our costs are generated in pound sterling and involve little or no currency
risk. We review our currency exposure on a continual basis and enter into hedges if we consider it necessary.

**_Credit Risk_**

Our principal financial assets are cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables and other receivables. The credit
risk associated with cash and cash equivalents is limited. Credit risk is managed by transacting with financial
institutions with high-quality credit ratings. Trade receivables comprise a large number of individually small
amounts from unrelated customers and are shown net of a provision for doubtful debts. Management estimates
the provision for doubtful debts based on a review of all individual receivable accounts, experience and known
factors at the end of the relevant period. The credit risk associated with these is minimal. We have no significant

**Selected Significant Judgments and Estimates**

The preparation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS requires management to make
judgments, estimates and assumptions in the application of accounting policies that affect reported amounts of
assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses during an applicable period.

Management periodically evaluates its estimates and judgments and bases them on historical experience and other
factors that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making
judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily available from other sources.
Actual results may differ from these estimates.

The estimates and assumptions that have the most significant effect on the amounts recognized in the financial
statements are discussed below. For a more comprehensive explanation of the accounting policies used in the
preparation of our consolidated financial statements, refer to Note 1 of our consolidated financial statements as of
and for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**_Exceptional Items_**

During the applicable periods, certain items are identified and separately disclosed as exceptional. Judgement is
applied as to whether the item meets the necessary criteria as per the accounting policy disclosed. This assessment
covers the nature of the item, cause of occurrence and the scale of impact of that item on reported performance.

**_Going Concern_**

The directors exercise judgement when concluding on going concern as the basis of preparation of the financial
statements. See also “Risk Factors—We may be unable to continue as a going concern.”

**_Presentation of deferred tax_**

The tax base has changed in the 52-week period ended September 24, 2023 as a result of property, plant and
equipment now being revalued and measured at fair value. This has resulted in a movement in the deferred tax
liability and a portion of this movement does not directly relate to the revaluation. IAS 12 does not provide any
guidance on how to allocate this overall movement between the income statement and other comprehensive
income and management have used judgement to allocate this on a reasonable basis to reflect both the unwinding
of existing deferred tax liabilities due to the change in tax base through the income statement and revaluation
through the statement of comprehensive income.

**_Valuation of property, plant and equipment, and investment property_**

Properties are measured at fair value reflecting market conditions at the balance sheet date. Gains and losses
arising from changes in the fair value of property, plant and equipment are recognized in the revaluation reserve
except where they reverse a revaluation decrease relating to the same asset previously recognized as an expense
in the income statement in which case the reversal of the revaluation decrease is recognized in the income
statement. Any deficit arising from the revaluation exercise is taken to the revaluation reserve to the extent that
there is a surplus in place relating to the same asset. Any further decrease in value is recognized in the income
statement as an expense. Changes to the fair value of investment properties are recognized in the income statement
in the period in which they arise. Fair values are determined based on an annual revaluation by external valuers.

Licensed land and buildings are revalued annually to fair value in accordance with RICS Valuation–Global
Standards and IFRS 13. The valuation methodology uses an estimation of the fair maintainable trade (FMT) of a
pub held in PPE and commercial rent for a property held as an investment property and then applies a multiple.
The FMT is estimated based on historic trends and projected future income whilst multiples are determined by

96


-----

our valuers with reference to each specific asset and market information. For more details on the FMT and multiple
see Note 14 of our consolidated financial statements as of and for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023. The
valuers also make reference to market evidence of transaction prices for similar properties. An adjustment to any
of these assumptions could lead to a material change in the property valuation. The highest and best use for the
licensed land and buildings is assumed to be their current use by the Group, principally due to the legal restrictions
imposed by the agreement with the publican, planning regulations and the financial implications of a change of
use given those restrictions and the Group’s business model. However, consideration is given to an alternative
highest and best use if there are factors that indicate that such an alternative use exists which is physically possible,
legally permissible and financially feasible.

**_Impairment of goodwill_**

Goodwill is not amortized but is tested for impairment annually, or more frequently where events or changes in
circumstances indicate that the carrying value may be impaired. Goodwill is stated at cost less any impairment.
For the purpose of impairment testing, goodwill is allocated to cash generating units that are consistent with the
Group’s operating segments. As properties move between segments the associated goodwill will also be
transferred.

**INDUSTRY**

**UK Pubs and Bars Overview**

We predominantly operate in the pubs and bars sector in the United Kingdom, which continues to be a significant
part of the wider UK drinking-out and eating-out market. In the United Kingdom, this sector consisted of
approximately 43,150 pubs and bars as of the end of 2023, according to CGA.

The pubs and bars sector in the UK experienced significant disruption due to the outbreak of the COVID-19
pandemic and the subsequent government intervention, which resulted in the temporary closure of pubs and bars,
severely impacted trading in 2020 and 2021. According to CGA, the pubs and bars sector in the UK has, in the
year ended December 31, 2023, recovered to similar levels as measured by sales as compared to the year ended
December 31, 2019, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with pub companies experiencing particularly strong
trading in the past 12 months.

**_Overview of Ownership in the United Kingdom_**

Public houses have been part of British culture for more than two millennia. More recently, about three decades
ago, the pub industry was dominated by six large brewers (Scottish & Newcastle, Allied, Bass, Courage, Grand
Met and Whitbread) who controlled just over half of all UK pubs and accounted for approximately 75% of UK
beer production.

In 1989, a report drafted by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission found that a complex monopoly existed in
favor of brewers who owned tied houses or who had tying agreements with free houses in return for loans (brewer
loans) at favorable interest rates. Subsequently, The Supply of Beer (Tied Estate) Order 1989 (“the Beer Order”)
was passed to force the sale of 50% of breweries’ pub estates in excess of 2,000 units by November 1992. This
led to the development of the independent pub company, which took over ownership of many of these pubs from
the breweries. These pub companies typically negotiate agreements with the breweries for the supply of beer and
then on-sell that beer to the pubs they own, thus intervening in the direct sale of beer from breweries to pubs.

Since then, pub companies have increased their ownership of pubs in Britain. In 2006, pub companies owned
approximately 54% of UK pubs, with the two largest, Punch Taverns and the legacy Ei Group, controlling
approximately 30% of the UK pub sector. The Beer Order was revoked in 2002 pursuant to the Supply of Beer
(Tied Estate) (Revocation) Order 2002, following a review by the Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which found that
the sector had undergone significant changes in ownership, such that concerns relating to brewers’ vertical
integration and the Beer Order were not relevant anymore.

The ownership of pubs in the United Kingdom is broadly spread across three main categories of owners:

- Brewer-owned pubs, typically operating under a ‘tied contract’;

- Independent pub companies that either manage pub operations by themselves or lease the pubs out to
tenants; and

- Independent pub owners, who are typically individuals with either a single pub/bar or a small portfolio
of sites.

**_Operational Formats_**

The UK pub sector can be categorized into a number of distinct business models, across pubs and bars. The pubs’
business models include, among others, Managed, Leased and Tenanted (of which some are commercial or freeof-tie properties) and independently owned. For bars, a variety of late night offerings exist, differentiated by the
tempo of the environment, variety of product offerings and target consumer base.

_Managed Pubs and Bars_

Managed pub companies directly employ central management and local staff and have complete control over the
sales format and product offering within each pub. As a result, they benefit from the entire revenue, are responsible
for all costs, and ultimately retain all of the net income generated from their operations. Managed pub operators
have performed particularly well within the pub industry over the past few years and have improved their market
share as compared to Leased and Tenanted pub operators and independent pubs. Managed pubs also typically
generate higher gross margins than publicans or independent pubs, as Leased and Tenanted pubs are generally

98


-----

required to purchase their beer at a premium from the pub companies that lease the pubs to them, while
independent pubs lack the scale to buy on terms as good as those from which large pub companies benefit. Apart
from the Stonegate Group, key operators within the Managed sector include Mitchells & Butlers and JDW, as
well as some of the estates of Marston’s, Greene King, Young’s and Fuller’s.

_Operator-run Pubs_

Operator-run pubs are owned by the pub company and are run by self-employed operators who receive a
percentage of revenue generated and are responsible for organizing and paying the staff. The remaining revenue,
other costs and management responsibility belong to the pub company. One of the key advantages of operatorrun pubs is the lower operational leverage as staff cost is directly linked to revenues. Additionally, these sites
benefit from having the Managed pub knowledge base with respect the areas of pricing, marketing, range and
scale while simultaneously benefitting from local operators who are embedded in the communities they serve.

_Leased and Tenanted Pubs_

Leased and Tenanted pubs are typically owned by a pub company or brewer but are operated by a third party
tenant or lessee, who normally pays below-market rent to the owner and is normally contractually obligated to
purchase the majority of its supply of drink products (in particular, beer) from the owner, an arrangement known
as the “tie.” Tied publicans typically enjoy support and certain benefits from pub companies as part of the
arrangement, such as marketing advice, capital investments or training courses. Importantly, the publican also
benefits from receiving living accommodation above the pub, allowing that person to cover quiet trading hours
without having to employ anyone. While the publican rents the building and fixtures and purchases the drinks
from the pub companies, the pub companies have limited direct influence on revenue generation (though there
can be ways to incentivize volumes sold through beer discounts) and limited exposure to the costs of the pubs, as
the pubs effectively operate independently and are responsible for their own operating costs (i.e., labor, food/drink,
energy and overheads). Following the acquisition of Ei Group, we are the largest Leased and Tenanted pub
company in the United Kingdom. Our main competitors in the Leased and Tenanted pubs segment are Star Pubs
& Bars, Punch Taverns, Greene King and Marston’s.

In July 2016, the Pubs Code introduced the MRO option allowing tenants to give notice to the landlord to opt to
pay rent at a free-of-tie commercial rate without requiring them to purchase drinks from the pub company. These
leases tend to be comparable to regular commercial real estate leases with upward rent reviews only. The typical
lease duration for commercial properties is 10 years or less.

_Independently Owned Pubs_

Independently owned pubs (sometimes known as “freehouses”) are generally smaller, standalone pubs owned by
private individuals who have free rein over the products offered. Their average revenue is generally similar to
tenanted pubs.

**Market Overview and Competitive Landscape**

**_Historical and Current Market_**


Lessee Pub owner


According to CGA, the total UK food and drinks market in outlets that have a license to sell alcohol on the
premises (the “on-trade” market) is estimated to have reached £55.9 billion in sales in 2023, of which pubs and
bars retail sales comprises £30.7 billion. Between 2015 and 2019, the pubs and bars market showed 3.0% growth
per year on average. During the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, the market value declined to £12.8 billion, before
recovering to above pre-pandemic levels after 2022. Throughout the same period, a reduction in the total number
of operating pubs and bars was observed, leaving the remaining pubs and bars to benefit from a more balanced
market position, capturing customers from those venues that closed down. Average selling prices have increased
as a result of factors such as the premiumization of drink offerings and underlying inflation, for example, the
average pub price of draught lager per pint has increased from £3.45 in 2015 to £4.57 in 2023. Further growth in
pub revenues is expected from increased food sales and higher traffic as a result of entertainment offered in pubs,
such as sporting events or live music. In 2023, the on-trade market in the UK is predominantly covered by
Managed and Leased and Tenanted establishments, with approximately 51% and 26% market share by value,
respectively.

100


-----

Pubs and Bars Wet and Dry Value (£bn)


_Source: CGA._

**_Supply of Pubs and Bars_**

The UK pubs and bars sector has historically been overcrowded with a number of unprofitable sites. However, as
unprofitable sites exit the market and the remaining profitable estates win customer and revenue shares from those
that have exited, the result is a more balanced market. According to CGA, supply of bars and pubs in the United
Kingdom has decreased from 51,630 sites in 2015 to 43,154 sites in 2023. Within this trend, Leased and Tenanted
pubs in non-prime locations closed down at a faster rate than pubs in the broader sector, resulting in pub operators
selling off the less profitable parts of their estates. We expect that pub operators will continue to close or sell
unprofitable sites in the future (albeit at a slower rate), providing stronger, more resilient pubs the opportunity to
increase market share. According to the CGA, the number of Leased and Tenanted pubs saw a decline of 31%
from 23,290 to 15,989 over the six year period from 2015 to 2023, with Managed pubs growing 13% over the
same period. We believe that this demonstrates that pub companies are recognizing the benefits of directly
investing in and operating their estates, including each estate’s approach to branding, through a Managed operating
model, as opposed to relying on their tenants to do so under the Leased and Tenanted operating model.

**_Volume and Market Value_**

From 2010 to 2019, although UK pub sector revenues increased over time, total alcohol volumes fell as a result
of a combination of factors. These factors included lower prices at off-license stores and supermarkets, the
smoking ban, the economic recession and a general cultural shift toward opting for premium or craft products
over alcohol quantity. Ultimately, these factors also led to lower alcohol consumption. Despite the lower level of
alcohol consumption, the on-trade drinks market remains stable and resilient, with CGA estimating continued
revenue growth in the coming years.

**_Pricing_**

The on-trade price of beer has historically increased broadly in line with the consumer price index (CPI), although
recent inflation highs in 2022 and 2023 have resulted in CPI increasing ahead of the price of on-trade drinks. The
price of on-trade beer, off-trade beer and wine & spirits increased by 19.7%, 16.9% and 15.9% from January 2017
to January 2023 respectively. Over the longer period of 2005-2023, on-trade beer prices have increased by a
compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 3.2% annually, whereas off-trade beer prices have increased by a
significantly lower rate by a CAGR of 1.3% annually, in the same period. We believe that the high growth
achieved in on-trade prices and the focus on promoting an increased range of offerings, including higher priced
cocktails and premium products, are the primary factors that have resulted in growth of total pub revenues despite
a fall in volumes.

**_Premiumization and On-trade Drinks Market_**

The on-trade market can be distinguished into four segments: the value segment, which covers venues that draw
price conscious customers; the mainstream segment, which covers branded and high street venues offering food
and drink at mid-range prices drawing middle- and high- income customers; the premium mainstream segment,
which covers experience-driven venues that provide a higher proportion of premium products and the premium
segment, which covers casual dining outlets and venues delivering high-end drink and food offerings.

Customer demand for premium drinks such as craft beer, craft cider, micro-distillery spirits, premium mixers and
cocktails has been growing. Within the on-trade market, the rapid growth in the popularity of cocktails has been
particularly important in increasing the profitability of pubs and bars, driving increased volumes for spirits and
allowing pub and bar operators to reposition themselves with higher per unit priced drinks.

**_Competitive Environment_**

The pubs and bars sector in the United Kingdom faces competition from leisure and service providers such as
retail outlets for the sale of food and drink and restaurants (in particular casual dining outlets), as well as offlicense shops and supermarkets. Pubs and bars have therefore been increasing the breadth of their offerings in
terms of product range, experience-led occasions and access to broader demographics through late night offerings.
The wider on-trade food and drinks market can be broadly segregated on the basis of consumer age and
demographics. As seen in the market positioning map below, the operational flexibility of our various brands
enables us to target consumers across both age and demographics without hurting our own revenues, which we
believe gives us a competitive edge.

While the pubs and bars sector in the United Kingdom remains fragmented, it has undergone periods of
consolidation through joint ventures, mergers and acquisitions. This has led to the emergence of certain large
competitors with considerable financial and operational resources. We are the largest pub company in the United

Major pub owners in the UK can be categorized into a few archetypes. The following archetypes are associated
with the corresponding strategies:

   - Pub rental revenue generators: Focus on owning a large portfolio of pubs and generating revenue through
leasing or renting pubs to tenants.

   - Scale-driven maximizers: Maintain direct control over pub operations, ensuring consistent experience
and maximised profitability through economies of scale. The breadth of the portfolio allows for efficient
allocation of resources, with investment directed towards the highest-returning opportunities.

   - Brewery affiliated networks: Promote and sell their own beer brands through a network of owned pubs,
driving brand recognition and dedicated sales for their products.

   - Integrated leisure operators: Operators who integrate their pubs into their leisure portfolio in order to
enhance guest experiences, attract customers and provide convenient entertainment offerings.

   - Independent pub operators: Entrepreneurial owners establishing unique experiences, often focusing on
local clientele and fostering a strong sense of community within their establishment.

**Overview of Trends Within the Wider Drinking-Out Market**

Pubs continue to hold cultural and social significance for UK consumers, and consumer spend has been resilient
despite macroeconomic-driven fluctuations impacting disposal income. The UK pub customer base has proved to
be resilient in the face of the cost of living crisis, reinforcing the view that eating and drinking out of the household
remains an important part of the average consumer’s lifestyle. We do not expect this to be significantly impacted
despite spending pressures on households. According to Barclaycard data, annual spend growth in pubs and bars
has outpaced restaurants during 2023 and year-to-date May 2024. In restaurants, customers have reduced the
number of visits, but spend greater amounts when they go out. In pubs, customers have retained the habit of
visiting a pub, backing up the view that visiting the pub forms part of a typical pub customers everyday life, but
their spend per transaction has been growing at a lower rate. As a result, overall Year-on-Year (YoY) change in
spending has been strong for bars, pubs & clubs, while restaurants have struggled in the post-pandemic
environment, as shown by the graph below. In particular, the rebound in pub spend at a faster rate than other ontrade categories following the COVID-19 pandemic demonstrates the prioritization of consumer spend at pubs
versus other leisure categories.

In the period following the COVID-19 pandemic, consumers faced a cost of living crisis which strained household
finances as CPI including owner occupiers' housing costs (CPIH) inflation increased to a peak of 9.6% in the

environment through buy-to-let mortgages. However, CPIH inflation has abated in recent months, decreasing to

on discretionary expenditure, of which eating and drinking out of the household is a key component.

As a consequence of the COVID-19 pandemic, there has also been an increase in employees working from home
and adapting to hybrid working patterns, which has resulted in higher growth for pubs operating in suburban areas.

Younger generations are driving a decline in alcohol sales volumes due to their reduced alcohol consumption.
Nonetheless, they are boosting the market value by exhibiting a preference towards higher-end specialty beverages
and spirits. According to the BBPA, wine and spirits consumption has grown at a CAGR of 1.2% and 2.1%,
respectively, from 2000 to 2022, whilst beer consumption has declined by a CAGR of 1.2%, in the same period.

**_Experiential and Leisure Propositions_**

Consumer trends are now showing a growing interest in differentiated and memorable experience-led offerings.
With clear demand for a wider offering and service, leading operators have been upping their entertainment and
events to satisfy this shifting consumer preference, including televising major sporting events, hosting music
festivals, live music nights, escape rooms, garden games and raffles, all of which serve to retain existing
customers, attract the younger adult market (particularly among the 18 to 34 segment) and persuade infrequent
pub- and bar-goers to visit more often. Providing better and more complete experiences and leisure-based
entertainment in pubs and bars can lead to an increase in footfall and volumes.

**_All-Day Trading Formats_**

With the changing profile of the average consumer and a movement to all-day trading, there has been an
accompanying shift in demand for particular types of products and site formats. Pubs have proven to be
increasingly popular venues for out-of-home dining as customers continue to look for value by choosing pubs
over more expensive restaurants when eating out. The food offering increases the footfall in pubs and is an
additional growth driver for the overall pub industry.

**_Digitalization_**

Engagement with technology is impacting the way in which pub and restaurant owners interact with their
customers, specifically the millennial consumer demographic. The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated the
digitalization trend in the pubs and bars sector. Given the restrictions put in place by the UK government,
hospitality venues relied heavily on the use of technology in order to enforce social distancing measures.

107


-----

Moreover, the mobile channel is becoming increasingly important, in particular for booking and reservations,
enhancing the overall customer experience, engaging with customers outside the guest visit, speeding up payment
and real time customer feedback.

**_Increasing Input Costs_**


Input costs for pub operators have increased across key categories including energy, food and labor, with the latter
partially driven by staffing and recruitment challenges.

In terms of labor, the National Living Wage (NLW) for employees over the age of twenty-one (the highest level
of NLW) increased by 9.8% from £10.42 to £11.44 from April 1, 2023 to April 1, 2024. The OBR forecasts that
NLW will increase at 2.8% per year between 2024 and 2027. Not only does this impact employees earning the
NLW, but also it may have a knock-on effect on higher wage earners within the business.

**_Regulatory Environment_**

The pubs and bars industry in the United Kingdom is subject to laws and regulations across a variety of operational
areas and related activities. These include premise licensing, pub licensing, the rental relationship between tied
tenants and large pub companies, alcoholic drinks control, late-night levies, leisure (gaming) machines,
employment, minimum wages, competition, health and safety, sanitation, drink driving, data protection and access
for the disabled.

In the UK, there is a growing acknowledgement from politicians that the property rates system is archaic as the
UK has moved to an online-focused retail environment. Accordingly, in 2019, the government introduced business
rates relief under the Retail, Hospitality and Leisure (“RHL”) scheme for certain retail properties. This scheme
was recently extended to its fifth year up until April 2025 and provides eligible RHL properties with a 75%
business rates relief up to a certain subsidy control cap.

**_Alcohol Duty_**

Alcohol duty is a tax charged at the point of production or importation of drinks of alcoholic strength exceeding
1.2% alcohol by volume. The alcohol duty system was simplified on August 1, 2023, with the new system
introducing measures to tax alcohol according to strength. Duty rates differ between beers, ciders, wines, spirits
and other fermented products, with higher rates of alcohol duty being levied on products with higher alcohol level.
This policy is an advantage for the pub industry as high proportion of sales is generated through beers and ciders,
drinks at the lower end of the spectrum of alcohol strength.

Since the implementation of the new duty system, the duty rates have been frozen at their levels at Autumn
Statement 2023 and Budget 2024. The rates are due to stay at this level until February 2025. Afterwards, the
government will revert to increasing duty rates in line with Retail Price Index from August 1, 2024. Meanwhile,
the UK government has also increased the value of draught relief, reducing the tax burden on alcoholic beverages
sold in on-trade venues, such as pubs, from 5.0% to 9.2% for beer, cider, flavored alcohol products and from
20.0% to 23.0% for wine and spirits products.

**BUSINESS**

_In this section, all references to the Group are to the Company and its Subsidiaries (which, includes the Stonegate_
_Group and Platinum Group); all references to Stonegate Group are to the Company and its Restricted_

**Overview**

We are the largest pub company in the United Kingdom based on the number of sites (4,414 Group sites and 3,380
Stonegate Group sites, as of April 7, 2024). We began our trading operations in November 2010 with the
acquisition of 333 pubs from Mitchells & Butlers and, through a series of strategic acquisitions, including the Ei
Acquisition, we are now the largest pub company in the United Kingdom. Since 2010, we have acquired
businesses and assets in order to geographically diversify our presence across the United Kingdom, providing
exposure to regional markets and a number of operating models, formats and brands that provide a diverse and
resilient financial profile. We continually evaluate opportunities to strategically acquire individual sites in
situations where those sites are a particularly good fit for our existing business.

We have a strong real estate backing based on an estate of predominantly freehold properties, approximately 81%
by number of Group sites and approximately 90% by value (as of September 24, 2023) and a Group property asset
value of £4.1 billion (as of September 24, 2023). Within Stonegate Group, which has a property asset value of
£3.2 billion (as of September 24, 2023), our freehold estate comprises approximately 76% by number of sites and
approximately 88% by value, in each case as of September 24, 2023. We have a strong presence in London and
the southeast region of the United Kingdom and have diverse operating models, formats and brands.

Our revenue is generated from a variety of sources, including drink sales (76.7% and 77.2% of our Group’s
consolidated revenue for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024) and food
sales (10.4% and 9.8% of our Group’s consolidated revenue in the same periods). We believe that our diverse,
resilient and agile business across operating models, formats and brands, led by our experienced and reputed
management team, is instrumental in driving our revenue growth. Our Group’s revenue, operating profit, and loss
after taxation on a historical basis for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 were £1,719 million, £68 million
and £155 million, respectively, and for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024 it was £916 million, £190 million and
£4 million. Stonegate Group’s revenue for the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024 was £1,594 million and Stonegate
Group Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA for the 52 weeks ended April 7, 2024 would have been £411.6 million.

The pubs and bars sector in the UK experienced significant disruption due to the outbreak of the COVID-19
pandemic and the subsequent government intervention, which resulted in the temporary closure of pubs and bars,
severely impacted trading in 2020 and 2021. However, according to CGA, the pubs and bars sector in the UK has,
in the year ended December 31, 2023, recovered to similar levels as measured by sales as compared to the year
ended December 31, 2019, prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, with pub companies experiencing particularly strong
trading in the past 12 months.

We operate three main business segments: Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run:

  - _Leased and Tenanted: Within our Leased and Tenanted segment, Pub Partnership is our principal_
business activity following the completion of the Ei Acquisition. In addition, this segment also includes
commercial properties which consist of free-of-tie pubs and non-pub properties that are operated and
managed by third-party leaseholders on arms-length agreements. A key feature of the Pub Partnership
operating model is the tie arrangement, whereby most Pub Partners have agreed under their lease or
tenancy agreements to purchase beer and other beverages through us. The tie arrangements, along with
rental income, provide us with resilient and recurring earnings. As of April 7, 2024, the Group has 3,019
Leased and Tenanted pubs, which includes 1,985 Leased and Tenanted pubs in the Stonegate Group with
the remaining 1,034 pubs in the Platinum Group.

  - _Managed Pubs: Our Managed pubs are owned and operated by us and derive their income predominantly_
from the retail sale of food and drinks, accommodation and gaming machines. We believe this segment
allows us to take advantage of the pubs we believe have a significant upside potential through direct
management by experienced pub managers and pub operators. Our Managed pubs are strategically
positioned to cater to different customer demographics, trends and occasions. Our Managed pubs are
classified into nine formats, Bars & Venues, Be At One, Popworld, Premium, Proper Pubs, Pub & Dining,

110


-----

Slug & Lettuce, Social Pub & Kitchen and Sports Bar & Grill. In addition, within our Managed Pubs
business segment, we also have entered into 48 joint ventures with experienced retail partners. As of
April 7, 2024, we had 803 pubs operating within our Managed segment, all within the Stonegate Group.

  - _Operator-run Pubs: The Operator-run pubs are run by self-employed operators under our guidelines for_
managed pub operations, with a sports, entertainment and drink-led retail offering but typically a limited
food offering. The self-employed operator is paid a fixed percentage of revenue and is responsible for
employing all of the on-site staff. Accordingly, we benefit from low levels of operational gearing,
resulting in resilient earnings, downside protection and proportionally lower central costs to operate
Operator-run pubs. We operate these pubs under the Craft Union format, with one clear retail offer that
is drinks-led with quality beers at affordable prices, served in local, well-invested facilities, with audio
visual equipment for sports and entertainment. We believe that the structure of the Operator-run model
supports superior return on capital investment, as well as provides for higher levels of downside
protection given that we retain all revenue and meet all costs (other than staff costs, which are paid by a
self-employed operator who receives a percentage of revenue in order to do so). As of April 7, 2024, we
had 584 pubs operating within our Operator-run segment, all within the Stonegate Group.

**Our Strengths**

Our key credit strengths include the following:

**_Attractive and stable market, growing with a shrinking pub footprint_**

Prior to the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK pubs and bars market demonstrated stable long-term
growth, increasing at a compound annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 3.0% between 2015 and 2019 to reach a
total industry revenue level of approximately £29.5 billion in 2019. Following two years of disrupted business
and operations due to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK pubs and bars market recovered to preCOVID- 19 levels in 2022, and CGA forecasts growth in the sector to be approximately 2.8% during the period
from 2023 to 2029. We expect that this stable market growth, coupled with a continued reduction in the number
of establishments in the sector, to be beneficial to the remaining establishments such as the Group.

**_UK’s largest pub company benefitting from economies of scale_**

We have a high-quality and sustainable pub and bar estate. The quality of our estate is evident in our geographic
distribution and overall profile of our pubs. Our pubs are favorably weighted towards more suburban and rural
areas as well as towards London and areas in the southeast region of the United Kingdom. Additionally, our pubs
have diverse operating models, formats and brands, which we believe provides higher rental income and higher
drink sales based on a higher volume.

Our position as the United Kingdom’s largest pub company affords the business significant benefits of scale in
comparison to smaller pub companies in the United Kingdom. In terms of negotiating procurement terms, we
benefit from enhanced bargaining power with suppliers and service providers as a result of our size and
purchasing volume. In terms of operating leverage, we have higher revenue potential as our portfolio absorbs
the fixed costs associated with a pub company more effectively. Our operational expertise is a key benefit of
our scale, as it allows us to disseminate operational best practices across our estate to increase profitability, as
well as to access substantial data to inform key decisions such as strategic pricing and promotional initiatives.
Additionally, the size of our estate creates significant headroom for operational improvement across our portfolio
and value accretive capital opportunities, including the ability to convert and carry out expansionary
refurbishment, and the breadth of our portfolio allows for an efficient allocation of resources, where investment
is directed towards the highest returning opportunities.

Our diversification and significant scale position us to compete more effectively than other market participants,
delivering greater value to our stakeholders, including tenants, employees, customers and local communities.

**_Proven platform with a resilient, multi-offering business model_**

Our business is divided across three reporting segments, acting as a landlord for the Leased and Tenanted segment,
a proprietary pub operator for the Managed Pubs segment and a partner for third party operators for the Operatorrun segment.

As we are flexible in applying the format best suited to the demographic trends or customer base of a certain area,
we are able to overlay the appropriate brands and formats across our portfolio to maximize the performance of
our estate. Our multiple formats allow us to maintain a significant presence in growing cities without adversely
affecting sales at our pubs in adjacent locations, as compared to single-format operators that are limited to catering
to select target groups. Thanks to our multiple formats, we are also able to target a wide customer demographic
while being able to cater to various consumer trends.

Our multi-format platform brings diversity in terms of income sources (rental income, wholesale drink sales
and retail drink and food sales), locations (distribution throughout the United Kingdom with a weighting in

more profitable areas such as London and the southeast region of the United Kingdom), operating models
(Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run).

**_High-quality and primarily freehold real estate portfolio_**
