**Our Strategies**

As the business has recovered from the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and is now operating in a steady
state, we intend to pursue the strategies set out below to take advantage of the attractive supply and demand
market dynamics.

**_Business as usual_**

 - _Leased and Tenanted: Within our Leased and Tenanted segment, we plan to operate the Pub Partnership_
business, our main business, in its existing form. We believe that the estate is of high quality, having
been shaped into a strong and profitable business by strategically disposing of underperforming, smaller

114


-----

and secondary assets over time. We intend to continue to invest in the Leased and Tenanted portfolio to
ensure that our Pub Partners have the infrastructure that they require to provide the best customer
experience and to increase site profitability, ensuring the resilience of our income.

 - _Managed Pubs: Our strategy for the Managed Pubs business includes continued capital investments,_
responsiveness to industry trends, pricing improvements, labor efficiency and the implementation of
operational best practices across our estate.

 - _Operator-run: We continue to leverage our Managed Pub expertise in our Operator-run estate,_
combining best practice from Managed Pubs in a format where there is limited operational gearing.
We will continue to be innovative with the formats deployed, focusing primarily on the proven Craft
Union format.

**_Asset optimization strategy_**

We intend to maintain our commitment to asset optimization through capital investment and to capital recycling
through disposals, as we continue to improve our business performance and further increase our market share.
We have a sizeable pipeline of opportunities in our portfolio, which provides for strong investment and growth
opportunities in the future. Our commitments will be primarily focused on conversions to the Operator- run
model where we can use our flexibility and innovation in ensuring the most suitable format is implemented, in
particular, on converting the majority of applicable pubs to our Craft Union format.

We expect that our capital program going forward will be weighted towards pubs in suburban locations in order
to maximize our returns in the current trading environment. However, the scale of our potential pipeline allows
us to be flexible when selecting investment opportunities and we will remain alert to any changes in underlying
consumer trends and adjust our capital investment strategy accordingly, to the extent necessary. We intend to
capitalize on our ability to deliver market-leading operating performance across the Leased and Tenanted,
Managed Pubs and Operator-run models, particularly in light of the value creation opportunities provided by the
low operating leverage inherent in the Operator-run model. These strategies are discussed in more detail below.

Supported by our established asset management function, assuming a steady state of business and in line with
our strategy to invest in value enhancing operating models, we currently expect to convert approximately 50
pubs a year over the next 6 years from the Leased and Tenanted segment to mainly the Operator-run and a few
to the Managed Pubs segment. We have been historically successfully in converting our pubs between operating
format, with a historical record of approximately 40% return on investment for conversions during the 156
weeks ended April 7, 2024.

_Expand the Operator-run model to capture retail economics_

We believe we can create value by improving the existing Craft Union pubs and converting suitable Leased and
Tenanted pubs into the Craft Union format. We estimate that we will invest, on average, approximately £150,000
to £200,000 per pub to convert Leased and Tenanted pubs into Operator-run pubs, with high performing Leased
and Tenanted sites selected for this conversion, which benefits from the labor cost arbitrage of the tenanted
model and allows for greater control of investment, format and operations. The conversion allows us to capture
the full retail margin on food and drink sales, whilst minimizing exposure to labor costs. This would allow us
to capture Operator-run retail economics, in which we are targeting an estimated return on investment of
approximately 41% as illustrated in the chart below.

Operator-run pubs are run by self-employed operators who receive a fixed percentage of the revenue generated
at these pubs and are responsible for organizing and paying staff. This operating model provides the benefits of
a Managed Pub model, in terms of control over investments, formats and operations (e.g., in areas of pricing and
marketing), together with the capture of retail economics, while also providing certain benefits of the Leased
and Tenanted model, in terms of allocating responsibility to the pub operator for labor, staffing and other costs.
These pubs tend to be drink-led with no food offering and have a sports focus. We believe that the Craft Union
format is particularly well suited for drink-led pubs with lower revenues.

_Conversions from Leased and Tenanted to Managed Pubs_

We expect to convert a number of Leased and Tenanted pubs into Managed Pubs. Our Leased and Tenanted
estate provides a large pipeline for these conversions and we currently expect to convert approximately 5 pubs
a year from Leased and Tenanted to Managed Pubs.

We generally expect these conversions to result in higher profitability. Above a minimum level of sales,
Managed Pubs typically generate incremental profit on a unit basis when compared to a Leased and Tenanted
pub by capturing profit that would otherwise have been retained by tied publicans in the Leased and Tenanted
model. Additionally, through our capital investments program, whereby we estimate we will invest, on average,
approximately £300,000 to £350,000 per pub to implement these conversions, we are targeting an estimated
return on investment of approximately 20% as illustrated in the chart below.

_Conversions from Managed Pubs to Operator-run_

pubs generating approximately £10,000 to £12,000 in AWT, of which approximately £1,000 is related to food sales,

_Expansions_

In addition to the conversions, an important aspect of our asset optimization strategy going forward is
concentrated on investing in the refurbishment and upgrading of assets in the existing estate. The strategy
includes each of the Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run segments, with a total of
approximately 300 to 400 sites a year, at a cost of approximately £30 to £40 million each year.

The strategy is predominantly focused on the Leased and Tenanted estate, targeting approximately 250 planned
expansions a year over the next 6 years, with management intending on accelerating its investment into the
Leased and Tenanted division beginning in the 2025 financial year. During the 156 weeks ended April 7, 2024,
expansion schemes in the Leased and Tenanted segment have delivered approximately 68% return on investment. The
average expenditure for the planned expansions is approximately £30,000 per Leased and Tenanted site until
2029 (with an annual increase in line with 2.5% inflation). Additionally, we are planning on targeting
approximately 100 Operator-run or Managed Pubs expansions a year over the next 6 years.

_Disposals_

Disposals are a key pillar of our asset optimization strategy. In addition to planned sale-and-leaseback of selected
Managed Pubs sites, we aim to opportunistically crystallize value through selective site disposals, which
predominantly consist of sites that are no longer core to our conversions or expansions strategy.

The disposal strategy contributes to our business strategic objectives of deleveraging, funding growth capital
expenditure and providing an opportunity to crystalize value at attractive multiples. From September 28, 2020
to April 7, 2024, we have received a total of £158.4 million in disposal proceeds, with a total of 290 sites disposed
of at run-rate multiples of 22.7x.

**_Continuous Optimization Initiatives of Business Operations_**

We continuously focus on delivering optimization through a number of business initiatives outlined below.

_Pricing_

Pricing is a key component of ensuring we continue to improve our margins, which has been particularly key to
our overall strategic objectives given the inflationary environment in the United Kingdom in the last 2 years, with
Consumer Price Index inflation reaching a peak of 11.1% in October 2022. Our current pricing strategy focuses
on offsetting cost inflation by raising prices via data-led strategic increases in our Managed Pubs and Operatorrun segments and maximizing price levers within the Leased and Tenanted segment.

For the Operator-run segment, we believe our pricing is currently below our peers’ pricing. Therefore, in the
near term, we are planning on capitalizing on price headroom to deliver strong price increases during the second
half of 2024, alongside a longer-term strategy to increase prices marginally ahead of inflation. For the Managed
Pubs segment, the higher-end positioning of the Managed Pubs business enables longer-term price increases

117


-----

above inflation, driven by premiumization trends. For our Leased and Tenanted business, price increases are
implemented through yearly price reviews in April and are limited to CPI inflation plus 3%. Additionally, the
pricing of the rental component of the Leased and Tenanted income is supported by predominantly index linked
tenancy agreements, which implement rent increases with inflation.

_Media_

We realize the potential for use of digitalization and technology to enhance our Group’s performance and
improve our margins. Our media strategy is focused on two key initiatives, first, the “Media” initiative, which
involves the installation of digital advertising screens at our Managed sites, and second, the MiXR App, which
is a cross portfolio loyalty application that engages customers across multiple brands.

The Media component of our strategy involves installing of digital advertising screens to exhibit promotional
content at Managed sites. We aim to have installed digital advertising screens at approximately 800 selected
sites by November 2024. The screens will feature premium brands to enhance the increasing trend of
premiumization among our customers, whereby customer demand for premium drink categories has been
growing, particularly for premium lager and craft beer. The screens will also provide additional revenue from
third-party advertising media sales and content.

The MiXR App is a newly launched loyalty application designed to encourage customers to pre-book visits to
pubs in our estate, as well as display our promotional initiatives. The application has been popular since its release,
with downloads continuing to perform ahead of the rate required to achieve our target of 1.5 million downloads by
September 2024. The MiXR App is designed to increase customer loyalty to our pub estate and increase the
frequency of visits by customers.

_Cost Rationalization_

We continue to focus on improving our margins, of which cost rationalization is a key part of the wider strategy.
Significant progress has been made towards the operational improvement of our business, in particular, cost
rationalization in our head office functions, in addition to further initiatives in place to support long-term
strategic initiatives. As part of our cost rationalization strategy, we are also focused on simplifying our overall
structure, including increased spans of control, automation of processes where applicable and cost reductions.

_Energy_

Wholesale energy prices increased rapidly from the second half of 2021 and into 2023 as a consequence of a
supply-demand imbalance, following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. Following this period of
volatile and elevated energy costs, we have taken steps to reduce energy consumption and otherwise mitigate
the impact of energy price volatility across our estate. There was a spike in prices during December 2022, but
prices fell back in early 2023 and have remained at levels well below their 2022 peak. However, they still remain
above their pre ‘energy crisis’ levels.

The pricing component of the energy strategy is focused on hedging energy prices to mitigate the impact of
volatility in future energy prices, with the Group hedging almost 100% and 75% of our expected electricity usage
for summer and winter 2024 and 98% and 78% of our expected gas usage for summer and winter 2024.
Additionally, to reduce consumption, we conduct periodic trainings and communication initiatives for our staff to
support reduced energy consumption.

**History**

We were incorporated in August 2010 in connection with our acquisition of approximately 333 pubs,
predominantly freehold, from Mitchells & Butlers and began our trading operations in November 2010. We have
since grown in size and scale through a series of strategic acquisitions. In 2011, we acquired Town & City, which
owned 226 leasehold pubs, thereby growing our geographical presence in the UK and helping us to develop our
formats to cover a wider demographic catchment. In 2013, we acquired 12 pubs from Living Room, which allowed
us to strengthen our presence in some of the major cities across the UK, including London, Manchester, Liverpool,
Glasgow, Edinburgh and Bristol. Again in 2013, through our acquisition of 78 pubs from Bramwell Pub Company,
we were able to further grow our reach within the UK, particularly in cities and towns where we did not have an
existing presence. In 2015, we acquired 15 pubs from Maclay, which allowed us to expand our presence in the
major cities and towns of Scotland, and we agreed to acquire 53 hand-picked pubs from TCG, allowing us to

118


-----

continue to strengthen our presence throughout the UK. In December 2016, we acquired Intertain, which operated
30 pubs across the UK predominantly under the Walkabout brand, a dedicated sports format popular with
millennials, expanding our reach to town and cities where previously we did not have any sites, such as Carlisle
and Lichfield. In 2017, we selectively acquired 13 pubs from JDW and acquired three central London pubs from
the Faucet Inn Sellers. In 2018 and 2019, we acquired 33 pubs pursuant to the Be At One Acquisition, 15 pubs
pursuant to the First Novus Acquisitions, 32 pubs pursuant to the Fever Bars Acquisition and six pubs pursuant
to the Second Novus Acquisitions. In addition, on March 3, 2020 we completed the Ei Acquisition, acquiring an
additional 4,028 pubs and combining Ei Group’s operation with ours. We continually evaluate opportunities to
acquire individual sites in situations where those sites are a particularly good fit for our existing business.

**Business Segments**

We operate three main business segments: Leased and Tenanted, Managed Pubs and Operator-run.

**_Leased and Tenanted_**

We acquired our Leased and Tenanted business segment pursuant to the Ei Acquisition. Within our Leased and
Tenanted segment, Pub Partnership is our principal business activity following the completion of the Ei
Acquisition, operating public houses under the Leased and Tenanted pub model. As of April 7, 2024, we had
2,711 pubs under the Pub Partnership model. Under our Leased and Tenanted business, we grant leases to, or
enter into tenancy agreements with, Pub Partners who operate the pubs as their own businesses and who must pay
rent and purchase beer and other drinks from us (or suppliers nominated by us) and enter into income sharing
arrangements with us in relation to income generated from leisure machines.

We have a shared interest with our Pub Partners in the success of the pubs they operate. In the equilibrium of
trade, in line with the expectations of both parties, the drink and dry rents are together aimed at representing a fair
return and payment for the use of the property. If we and the Pub Partner cooperate to increase alcoholic drinks
sales, then both parties will benefit from the higher profits. If the Pub Partner struggles and fewer alcoholic drinks
are sold, we, as landlord, will receive less drink rent and the Pub Partner will enjoy a lower effective rent.

We provide support to Pub Partners through a package of flexible lease agreements, capital investments and
proactive intervention of regional managers. In addition, we offer our Pub Partners a broad range of businessbuilding services to help them increase sales and reduce costs, and to operate their pubs efficiently and effectively.
Reducing the instances of business failure is one of our key strategies to maintain and grow revenue performance
as failures have usually had a significant impact on their income. As a result of our temporary concessions and
support to Pub Partners as well as a history of disposing of underperforming pubs, we have experienced an
improvement in the overall quality of the estate and a decline in pub failures.

The ability to mitigate the financial risks faced by Pub Partners during periods of economic challenge is a unique
attribute of the Pub Partnership business model. The proactive intervention of our regional managers to identify
and then avoid potential business failures is particularly important when Pub Partners are likely to be facing cost
pressures. The current inflationary macro-economic environment and cost of living crisis in the UK, exacerbated
by the war in Ukraine which has driven up energy and food prices in particular, has continued to pressure the
trading environment of our Pub Partners. While our Pub Partners have received benefits under government relief
schemes, such as the scheme to support energy bills of pubs and other businesses with a discount on business
energy unit rates, we have taken pro-active measures to support our Pub Partners. For instance, we have initiated
temporary concessions and discretionary support where short term cash flow is more challenging. As a result of
these initiatives, business failures across our Pub Partnership estate has remained low, at 2.4% the 52 weeks ended
September 24, 2023 and 1.9% for the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024.

In addition, we also have free-of-tie pubs and non-pub properties operated and managed by third-party
leaseholders on an arms-length agreement and as of April 7, 2024, we had 308 commercial properties, which are
traded as free-of-tie pubs. Following the completion of the Platinum Transaction, pursuant to which we have
transferred 1,034 pubs to the Platinum Group, Stonegate Group has, as of April 7, 2024, 1,985 Leased and
Tenanted pubs, consisting of 218 free-of-tie pubs and 1,767 tied pubs.

This business manages a developing portfolio of assets which we lease out to third parties on commercial property
terms and derives its income predominantly from rental payments and contributes to the diversification of earnings
by providing another source of recurring rental income.

**_Managed Pubs_**

Our Managed Pubs segment is comprised in its majority by pubs that are owned and operated by us. Therefore,
this segment allows us to take advantage of the pubs we believe have a significant upside potential through direct
management by experienced pub managers and pub operators. As of April 7, 2024, we had 803 Managed pubs (of
which 755 are Managed pubs operated by us and 48 are pubs operated pursuant to certain joint ventures entered
into by us with experienced retail partners). As these businesses are wholly or jointly owned and operated by us,
we directly benefit from revenue generated by their operation, including revenue from the sale of food, drinks and
accommodation and gaming machine income.

Our Managed pubs are managed on a regional basis with 52 area managers supporting seven operational directors,
as of April 7, 2024, who report to one managing director. Each pub is managed by a general manager is
incentivized to maximize profit through a bonus scheme.

Our Managed pubs are classified into nine formats, Bars & Venues, Be At One, Popworld, Premium, Proper Pubs,
Pub & Dining, Slug & Lettuce, Social Pub & Kitchen and Sports Bar & Grill. Our nine formats represent the
diversity of our offering, our wide geographical reach within the UK and our broad customer base. By operating
our Managed pubs through a multi-format strategy, we believe we have strategically positioned ourselves across
a wide range of consumer demographics, trends and occasions.

In addition, as of April 7, 2024, we also have 48 joint ventures with experienced retail partners. Under this
partnership model, we are allowed to work with carefully selected Managed pub operators to share in the benefits
of trading in certain high quality and specialist retail segments. This business predominantly operates in premium
consumer segments with attractive price elasticity and is therefore better able to mitigate the inflationary pressure
that is especially challenging for more value-oriented, food-led businesses.

During the integration of acquired pubs, we focus on achieving cost synergies and format integration. Starting
with our original acquisition of pubs from Mitchells & Butlers in August 2010 and from Town & City in June
2011, we have successfully managed the transition of pubs from Ember Inns, Vintage Inns, Toby Carvery, Crown
Carvery, Harvester, Scream, Living Room, Maclay and TCG, as well as of unbranded pubs and venues, into our
existing formats. Further, we fully integrated into our current formats the pubs we acquired from Intertain, Large
Bars, Faucet Inns, Ei Group (pursuant to the asset acquisitions from them in 2017) and Punch Taverns.
Furthermore, we have fully integrated into our current brands and formats the pubs we acquired pursuant to the
First Novus Acquisitions, Second Novus Acquisitions, the Fever Bar Acquisitions and the Be At One Acquisition.
Pursuant to the Ei Acquisition, in addition to conversion to Operator-run formats, we have also converted, and
plan to continue to convert select Leased and Tenanted pubs to Managed.

**_Operator-run_**

Our Operator-run pubs are run by self-employed operators under our guidelines for Managed pub operations, with
a sports, entertainment and drink-led retail offering but limited food offering. The self-employed operator is paid
a fixed percentage of revenue (typically around 19.5%) and is responsible for employing all the on-site staff and
as such we benefit from low levels of operational gearing, resulting in resilient earnings and a superior return on
capital investment, downside protection and proportionally lower central costs to operate our Operator- run pubs.

The Craft Union format, under which these pubs are run, has national coverage as a leading scale operator of
community pubs, with one clear retail offer that is drinks-led with quality beers, at affordable prices, served in
local, well-invested facilities, with audio visual equipment for sports and entertainment. Trading with limited
branding, Craft Union pubs have the look and feel of a local pub in the heart of communities. These pubs generally
offer no food, and instead focus on a sports and entertainment drink-led retail offer. They are run by self-employed

121


-----

operators who receive a percentage of the revenue generated in these pubs and who are responsible for employing
all staff in order to manage the day to day operations of the pubs, resulting in a proportionally lower central cost.

As of April 7, 2024, we had 584 pubs operating within our Operator-run segment.

We expect to continue to drive value by converting a number of pubs in our Leased and Tenanted segment to our
Operator-run segment, and thereby potentially increase the number of pubs that are run based on this model.

**Our Offering**

**_Drinks Offering_**

Our drinks sales, which include drink sales to customers in our Managed and Operator-run pubs and to our Pub
Partners in respect of our Leased and Tenanted pubs, made up 76.7% and 77.2% of our consolidated revenue for
the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024.

For our Managed and Operator-run businesses, we generally pass through drink price rises annually in April,
coinciding with alcohol duty increases in the UK. The government in the UK imposed a duty escalator which
commenced in April 23, 2009, pursuant to which duties on alcohol rise each year by 2% above the rate of inflation
(based on RPI). This duty escalation was removed from beer in the March 2013 budget and from spirits, wine and
made-wine, cider and perry in the March 2014 budget, while the March 2015 budget subsequently reduced duty
rates on beer, spirits and lower and high-strength cider, and froze duty rates on wine below 22% alcohol by volume
and high-strength sparkling cider. In the March 2016 budget, duty rates on wine and made-wine at or below 22%
alcohol by volume and high strength sparkling cider above 5.5% alcohol by volume rose at the same rate as RPI
inflation, but the UK government froze in cash terms the duty rates on beer, spirits and other drinks above 22%
alcohol by volume and still cider and lower strength sparkling cider. In the March 2017 budget, the duty rates on
alcohol manufactured in, or imported into, the UK rose at the same rate as forecast RPI inflation, and in the
November 2017 budget, duty rates on beer and most other spirits and ciders were frozen. In the October 2018
budget, duty rates on beer and most other spirits and ciders remained frozen but specifically duty rates on wine
and made-wine at or below 22% alcohol by volume and high strength sparkling cider above 5.5% alcohol by
volume rose at the same rate as RPI inflation.

In 2021, the UK government announced a new alcohol duty rates system based on alcohol by volume (“ABV”)
(replacing the previous system organized by drink classification). As of August 1, 2023, an increase in applicable
alcohol duty rates came into effect under the revised duty structure for alcohol products in line with RPI inflation.
Alcohol duty rates on beer, cider and wine were frozen following the Autumn 2020 budget. In order to provide
certainty to businesses, on November 22, 2023, the government extended the alcohol duty freeze to August 1,
2024, and on March 6, 2024 the government further extended the alcohol duty freeze to February 1, 2025. For
risks related to potential increases in alcohol duties to which we are subject, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to
_Our Business—Changes in regulations to which we are subject or the introduction of new regulations to which_
_we may become subject could have a negative effect on our business—The taxes and duties to which we are subject_
_may increase.”_

**_Food Offering_**

As of April 7, 2024, approximately 81% of our Managed pubs offered both food and drinks. We have established
strict standards and specifications for the food we source for our Managed pubs to help us ensure the quality and
consistency of the food products sold. The mix of food and drink sales at our Managed pubs varies over the course
of the day. On average, at these pubs, food accounted for 29.6% and 29.5% of all pre-6:00 p.m. sales across our
Managed pubs for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively.
Our food sales made up 10.4% and 9.8% of our consolidated revenue for the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023
and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively. Although drinks sales are the main focus of our Managed
Pubs business, food offering helps us maximize profitability.

For our Managed Pubs, we change food menus twice a year, once during spring and once during autumn, passing
through any price changes at the same time. We attempt to remain current with, and continue to effectively
address, customer preferences and consumer trends in the food and drink market. For our Managed Pubs, we also
review our food and drink inventory and supply management on an ongoing basis to ensure that our Managed
Pubs offering is responsive to customer demand and to changing customer and industry trends. For risks related
to our inability to keep up with these preferences and trends, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—

122


-----

_Consumer preferences and perceptions in relation to drinks and food may continue to change and we may be_
_unable to adapt to such changes.”_

**_Other_**

Our other sales, which include sales from amusement, admission fees, accommodation, gaming machines and
other sales (excluding rent revenue), made up 6.1% and 6.0% of our consolidated revenue for the 52 weeks ended
September 24, 2023 and the 28 weeks ended April 7, 2024, respectively.

**Our Property Estate**

**_Geographical Presence_**

Our pubs have a geographically diversified footprint across the UK that consisted of 4,414 sites as of April 7,
2024, with a strong presence in London and the southeast region of the UK. Following the completion of the
Platinum Transaction, pursuant to which have transferred 1,034 sites to the Platinum Group, Stonegate Group’s
estate consists of 3,380 sites, approximately 45% of which are located in town centers and approximately 55%
being located in rural or suburban locations.

We review our geographical footprint on an ongoing basis. In 2013, we acquired 12 pubs from Living Room,
which allowed us to strengthen our presence in some of the major cities across the UK, including London,
Manchester, Liverpool, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Bristol. Further, in 2013, through our acquisition of 78 pubs
from Bramwell, we were able to further grow our reach within the UK, particularly in cities and towns where we
did not yet have an existing presence. In 2015, we acquired 15 pubs from Maclay, which has allowed us to expand
our presence in the major cities and towns of Scotland, and in September 2015 we agreed to acquire 53 pubs from
TCG, allowing us to continue to strengthen our presence throughout the UK. In December 2016, we acquired
Intertain, which owned and operated 30 pubs across the UK predominantly under the Walkabout brand, a
dedicated sports format popular with millennials, expanding our reach to towns and cities where previously we
did not have any sites, such as Carlisle and Lichfield. In addition, we have also selectively acquired 13 pubs from
JDW and acquired three central London pubs from the Faucet Inn Sellers, and we continually evaluate
opportunities to acquire individual sites in situations where those sites are a particularly good fit for our existing
business.

In July 2018, we completed the Be At One Acquisition pursuant to which we acquired 33 bars spread across
central London (approximately 34%), outer London (approximately 19%) and regionally in the UK

located in certain towns and cities in the UK, such as Tunbridge Wells, Redditch and Basingstoke, and in a

**_Pub Investment Program_**

Since we began trading, and through April 7, 2024, we have refurbished (including expansions and conversions)
approximately 1,992 pubs that we operated, and we continue to invest in our managed estate. We have a focused
real estate investment program and take a disciplined approach to investment appraisal. For our managed estate,
we identify priorities for investment through bi-annual estate reviews and have put in place a multi-stage estate
review to ensure a disciplined approach to investment across our pubs. Sites are identified by analyzing current
performance, consumer trends and capacity opportunities. Investments are then approved through separate
operations, business and board committees. We consider the projected Group Return on Investment in deciding
whether to invest. Following the investment, performance is monitored at board meetings for the following three
years. In light of the COVID-19 pandemic and our efforts to manage cash outflows and preserve and build
liquidity, our ability to make investments in our estate had been limited for some time. During this time, we kept
discretionary spending at a minimum, and have taken a number of other steps to support our cash reserves.
However, with the removal of the remaining COVID-19 restrictions in England from July 19, 2021 onwards and
the gradual return to a steady state of business, we have resumed actively investing in our estate. In particular, for
the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, the Group spent £64 million on Investment Capital Expenditure, as
compared to £55 million during the 52 weeks ended September 25, 2022 and £18 million during the 52 weeks
ended September 26, 2021.

**_Pub Disposal Program_**

Disposals are a key pillar of our strategy to optimize our assets. We analyze each site in the combined estate and
assess its optimal format going forward. Pursuant to this analysis we have identified, and continue to do so an
ongoing basis, Leased and Tenanted sites which could generate more value as Operator-run pubs or Managed
pubs, and sites which could generate more value if disposed of, particularly where those sites may have attractive
alternative use opportunities. We have disposed of 86, 63, 140 and 36 trading sites during the 52 weeks ended
September 24, 2023, 52 weeks ended September 25, 2022, 52 weeks ended September 26, 2021 and 28 weeks
ended April 7, 2024, respectively.

**_Agreements with our Pub Partners_**

Our relationship with our Pub Partners is generally governed by the type and terms of the lease or tenancy
agreement in place between the Group and the individual Pub Partner. We currently enter into one of two main
categories of such lease or tenancy agreement with our Pub Partners, under which the tied publican operates the
pub as either a lessee or a tenant and agrees to pay the rent specified in the relevant agreement. The two main
categories of our existing leases are: (i) standard lease (up to ten years) and (ii) standard tenancy (majority of
which are for five years). In addition, Ei Group had previously granted 157 agreements with a wider variety of
terms to expiry and they had also inherited some legacy agreements through acquisitions such that the estate
includes lease agreements of between five and 65 years and tenancy agreements of between three and five years.

As part of a lease or tenancy agreement, the tied publican also agrees in most instances that we are to be the sole
supply for certain products. These “tie” arrangements relate primarily to the publican’s purchase of beer, cider,
flavored alcoholic beverages, wines, spirits and minerals, sales of which generally constitute the majority of the
publican’s revenue. In other instances the publican agrees to pay us a tie release fee on an ongoing basis in
exchange for reduced purchase obligations whereby categories of beverages may not be subject to a tie
arrangement.

Standard leases are generally fully repairing, which means that the lessee is responsible for repairs to the premises
during the term of the lease, and are generally fully assignable after two years (subject to our consent, which is
not to be unreasonably withheld). Standard leases generally contain provisions for annual price index rent
adjustments.

Standard tenancies, which are short-term arrangements, involve us undertaking to carry out the majority of
structural repairs to the relevant pub and are generally not assignable and subject to an annual RPI or CPI rent
adjustment. Pub Partners are usually required to provide a deposit on entry into their tenancy agreement. Some
forms of lease and tenancy agreement contain landlord’s or tied publican’s options to break the lease or tenancy.
In addition, there may be circumstances in which we would allow a tied publican to terminate a lease or tenancy
agreement early, as it is in our interest to have a motivated tied publican in our pub.

The use of a lease or tenancy agreement and its terms and conditions vary according to the profit expectations,
risk assessment and plans which we and the publican may have for the pub concerned.

**Regulation**

Our operations are directly subject to, and indirectly affected by, extensive regulation, including in relation to pub
licensing, taxation, health and safety, sanitation, alcoholic drinks control and leisure (gaming) machines. Our
operations are also subject to regulation with regard to the environment, data protection, access for the disabled
and sales to younger customers (such as criminal prosecution for selling alcohol to minors under the age of 18
and allowing minors under the age of 16 to access pub premises without being accompanied by an adult). Some
of the regulations to which we are subject in England and Wales are discussed below. We are also subject to
regulations in Scotland such as the Licensing (Scotland) Act 1976. The regulatory framework in Scotland is
broadly consistent with that of England and Wales detailed below.

The responsibility to comply with these regulations is typically distributed based on operational control over the
relevant sites. Generally, we are responsible for regulatory compliance in respect of our Managed Pubs whereas
Pub Partners are responsible for regulatory compliance in respect of the pubs that they operate.

**_The Business and Planning Bill_**

In June 2020, The Business and Planning Bill was introduced in the UK parliament. The bill seeks to mitigate the
impact of COVID-19 in the hospitality sector by simplifying and reducing the process and costs of obtaining
outdoor licensing by pubs, bars, restaurants. In particular, the bill contains provisions allowing for a fast track
application process for pavement licenses to allow street furniture as well as permitting on–licensed premises to

127


-----

automatically be permitted to provide off-sales. It also relaxes certain conditions for premises which already have
off sales authorizations.

**_Licensing Regulation_**

Licensing authorities are responsible for the licensing system in England and Wales, which is governed by the
Licensing Act of 2003 (the “Licensing Act”). There is a two tier system for licensing: premises licenses and
personal licenses.

**_Premises Licenses_**

Premises licenses are held by the Group. The grant of a premises license permits the conduct of licensable
activities at any premises. Licensable activities relevant to our operations are:

  - the sale of alcohol;

  - the provision of regulated entertainment; and

  - the provision of late-night refreshment, including the provision of hot food and drink after 11:00 p.m.

There is no requirement to renew a premises license every year, but an annual fee is payable, and non-payment of
the annual fee can lead to suspension of a premises license. Premises licenses are subject to various mandatory
conditions, one of which is that there has to be a designated premises supervisor in respect of each premises
license. A designated premises supervisor must by law hold a personal license.

The licensing authorities, when making any decision under the Licensing Act, have to do so in accordance with
the four licensing objectives, being:

  - the prevention of crime and disorder;

  - public safety;

  - the prevention of public nuisance; and

  - the protection of children from harm.

The concept of fixed hours for the sale of alcohol was removed with the advent of the Licensing Act in November
2005, and all licensed premises now have flexibility (provided applicable licensing fees are paid) in terms of the
hours that alcohol can be sold and entertainment and/or late night refreshment provided. This flexibility is however
tempered by the fact that any decision to grant a license has to be determined by the licensing authority, having
regard to both the licensing objectives, its statement of licensing policy and UK Home Office guidance.

Each licensing authority produces its own statement of licensing policy, which must be revised at least every five
years. The UK Home Office has produced its own guidance on the interpretation of the Licensing Act, which
licensing authorities must have regard to when making any decisions.

**_Personal licenses_**

Each designated premises supervisor must, by law, hold a personal license. Individuals apply to a licensing
authority for a personal license where they habitually reside. A personal license is personal to the individual and
is portable. The UK government has dispensed with the requirement to renew a personal license every ten years.

**_The Pubs Code and Market Rent Only (MRO)_**

The Pubs Code, introduced by the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015, came into effect on July
21, 2016 to regulate the relationship between tied pub tenants and the large pub-owning businesses, which rent
the pubs to tenants and sell them tied products.

The Pubs Code applies to all companies owning 500 or more pubs operating under tied leased and tenancy
agreements over five years in England and Wales, and is overseen and enforced by an independent Pubs Code
adjudicator. It provides tied publicans with a right, under certain circumstances, to replace their existing freelynegotiated tied agreements with the MRO arrangement. This enables tied tenants to opt out of the supply tie at
certain points or after certain exceptional events during the term of their lease agreements and to occupy the
premises on a standard commercial property lease, paying a market rent only. In the event that a tenant elects to
invoke this option, while income derived from the supply of tied drinks products would be partially offset by
increases in rent, it is possible that total income from that property would be adversely affected. The Pubs Code
was amended in March 2022 including changes to the MRO procedure concerning, among other things, the

128


-----

applicable timing requirements and the period a pub company must own 500 or more tied pubs in the previous
financial year in order to be subject to the Pubs Code (reduced from 6 months to 3 months). Accordingly, any
MRO event occurring after April 1, 2022 must follow the amended procedures. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating
_to our Business—Changes in regulations to which we are subject or the introduction of new regulations to which_
_we may become subject could have a negative effect on our business.”_

As of April 7, 2024, the extent of conversions to commercial free-of-tie agreements has been lower than was
originally anticipated as there have been only limited numbers of publicans opting in for the MRO option. As of
April 7, 2024, 886 out of 4,414 sites of the Group, or 20%, operated on a tied lease, and 298 out of 4,414 sites of
the Group, or 6.8%, operated on a free-of-tie lease. From the date of the introduction of the Pubs Code in July
2016 to April 7, 2024, there have been 2,379 rent review or agreement renewal events across 1,691 pubs which
could potentially have triggered an MRO request. As required under the Pubs Code, we have accepted 674 notices
by tenants of which 341 have been concluded by way of mutually agreed tied deals and 181 have resulted in new
mutually agreed MRO terms. In addition, 91 tenants left the pub, 25 claims were withdrawn by the tenant or had
other outcomes with the balance of 36 pending. Of the outstanding 36, 4 have been referred to the Pubs Code
adjudicator for determination. Of the 1,691 pubs referred to above, 734 pubs were still operated by the same tenant
on either tied or free-of-tie agreements as of April 7, 2024.

Although we believe that the lower-than-expected number of MRO requests reflects the tenants’ recognition of
the benefits of their existing tied agreements compared to the MRO alternative, we have reduced the number of
longer-term leases and increased the proportion of shorter-term tenancy agreements of up to five years in length
to minimize any adverse impact of the Pubs Code on our business. Since the introduction of the MRO concept in
November 2014, we have reduced the number of agreements that would fall under MRO from 3,035 to 886 as of
April 7, 2024.

**_Other Food Hygiene and Health and Safety Regulations_**

Local authority environmental health departments police these areas of regulatory compliance through regular
inspections and reactive enforcement visits following accidents and incidents. They seek to ensure compliance
with the Food Safety Act of 1990 and Health and Safety at Work Act of 1974. The risk to the business is that it
could be required to close and/or that it could be prosecuted, with consequential fines.

Government proposals on sentencing guidelines became effective in February 2016, and these may be used
retrospectively by the courts. Should a company be found guilty of an offense under any relevant legislation,
including corporate manslaughter, the penalties imposed will be significantly higher than in the past, potentially
running into millions of pounds. We manage this risk by the implementation of robust systems of training and
record keeping, assisted by the use of professional consultants to ensure compliance.

In April 2018, the UK Government implemented the soft drinks industry levy as part of its initiative to combat
obesity, which was revised in April 2023 to broaden the range of relevant beverages subject to the levy. We
actively oversee the number of sugary products offered and incorporate healthier non-sugary alternatives to align
with the regulatory framework.

**_Gaming Regulation_**

The provision of machines in premises which have the benefit of a premises license is governed by the Gambling
Act of 2005. All premises which have a premises license permitting the sale of alcohol for consumption on the
premises, granted under the Licensing Act, and which contain a bar at which alcohol is served, can provide
machines available for public use.

**_Categories of Machines_**

All such premises are automatically entitled to provide one or two machines of Category C or D (described below).
To benefit from the use of these machines, the premises license holder must notify the licensing authority that it
wishes to avail itself of the benefit of up to two Category C or D machines, and pay a £50 fee. There is no annual
fee payable for this automatic entitlement, once the initial fee has been paid. If the premises wish to have more
than two machines of Category C or D, then it must make an application to the licensing authority for a licensed
premises gaming machine permit. Such applications may need to be determined by the licensing authority at a
hearing. Once granted, an annual fee is payable for such permits.

Category C machines have a maximum cash prize of £100, and a maximum stake of £1. Only persons aged 18 or
over are allowed to play on Category C machines. Category D machines have different maximum stakes and

129


-----

prizes, but where the prize is money (which is the usual case), the maximum stake is ten pence, with a maximum
prize of £5. Persons under the age of 18 are allowed to play on Category D machines. Commonly, it is Category
C machines which are found in licensed premises.

**_Smoking Regulation_**

There is a legal requirement under the Health Act 2006 for premises which are classed as “enclosed” to be smoke
free. The restrictions do not currently apply to electronic cigarettes which allow the user to inhale nicotine in vapor
form, and which do not then produce any smoke, but otherwise apply to anything that can be smoked.

**_Noise Nuisance Regulation_**

Local authority environmental health officers are empowered by the Environmental Protection Act of 1990 and
associated legislation to police the issue of noise nuisance arising from commercial premises. They have the power
to issue fixed penalty notices in certain circumstances and to issue noise abatement notices requiring the cessation
of the nuisance. Informal discussion normally precedes such formal action but not always. The onus is on the
business to demonstrate due diligence in the prevention of such nuisance.

**_Other Recent Regulations_**

On 6 April 2022, the UK Government introduced the Calorie Labelling (Out of Home sector) (England)
Regulations 2021 which required businesses with more than 250 employees to display calorie information on nonpackaged food and soft drink menus. These regulations and other future initiatives that result in a requirement for
restaurants, cafes and pubs to display nutritional information on their menus, including for alcoholic drinks and
other related requirements, could give rise to additional compliance costs for us in relation to our Managed and
Operator-run pubs.

On May 2, 2023, the UK Government published the draft Terrorism (Protection of Premises) Bill (“Martyn’s
Law”) which puts premises owners under a duty to consider the threat from terrorism and implement proportionate
mitigating measures. Among other categories, Martyn’s Law also applies to premises with a maximum capacity
of over 100 people, which are required to implement certain safety preparedness measures and policies, including
training, information sharing and completion of a preparedness plan to embed practices such as locking doors to
delay attackers progress or knowledge on lifesaving treatments that can be administered by staff whilst awaiting
emergency services. Martyn’s Law is expected to be adopted as law in the coming months.

**Environmental Matters**

As part of our corporate social responsibility program we have implemented a number of schemes on
environmental matters.

We collaborate with ERM International, a consultancy firm focused solely on sustainability, to perform scenario
analysis to identify potential climate-related risks and opportunities and understand how changes to the climate
and the transition to a low-carbon economy may impact our risk or opportunity profile.

We partner with Olleco in the recycling of our used cooking oil. Our used oil is refined into a range of products
such as industrial oils and renewable fuels. For the 52 weeks ended September 24, 2023, we collected 942,000
liters (or 865 metric tons) of used cooking oil, which is the equivalent of saving 2,008 metric tons of carbon. For
the 52 weeks ended September 25, 2022, we collected 835,000 liters (or 767 metric tons) of used cooking oil,
which is the equivalent of saving 2,777 metric tons of carbon.

We also work in partnership with Veolia Environmental Services for waste collection and recycling services.
Veolia provides four waste stream services covering general waste, mixed recycling, glass recycling and food
recycling, which assists us with reaching our zero waste to landfill target. As of September 24, 2023, 100% of our
waste is diverted from landfill and 66.6% is recycled. Therefore, as a result, we have been able to significantly
reduce the amount of waste that is sent to landfills. This is the equivalent of saving over 1.2 million kg of carbon
over the last 12 months. We use smart energy meters to monitor and manage energy usage, so to be as efficient as
possible to help reduce consumption.

Along with other key players in the hospitality industry, we are an active member of the Zero Carbon Forum, a
non-profit organization having the aim of sharing best practices on reducing energy consumption, as well as
defining and implementing a net zero strategy to drive sector-wide change.

130


-----

For Managed and Operator-run pubs, we operate through a self-sustained water supply and cooperate with service
providers such as Waterscan and other wholesalers to ensure that the water consumption is at the lowest level
possible.

We believe that we do not currently have any outstanding material environmental compliance costs or
environmental liabilities. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business—We could be liable for
_environmental compliance costs at our properties.”_

**_Producer Compliance Schemes_**

We are an “obligated packaging producer” in respect of packaging waste under the Producer Responsibility
Obligations (Packaging Waste) Regulations 2007 (the “2007 Regulations”). Producers of packaging must ensure
that a proportion of their products is recovered and recycled in accordance with EU requirements which have been
transposed into national legislation. We are registered as a packaging waste producer. Our Managed pubs have
the facilities to recycle 100% of the glass used in the business.

**_Trade Effluent Discharge Consents_**

Under the Water Industry Act 1991, a consent must be obtained (or an agreement entered into) with a local water
and sewerage company in order to discharge liquid effluent from trade or industrial premises into (a) a public foul
sewer; or (b) a private sewer that connects to a public foul sewer. We hold the necessary trade effluent discharge
consents for our head office and our Managed Pubs.

**_Asbestos_**

The Control of Asbestos Regulations 2012 impose a duty to manage Asbestos Containing Materials (“ACMs”)
in non-domestic property such as by taking reasonable steps to locate ACMs; checking their condition; assessing
the risk of exposure to such materials; taking any necessary action to address any such identified risks and
maintaining a register of ACMs. The primary duty to manage falls upon the person or organization that has the
responsibility for the repair and maintenance of the property.

Any non-compliance could lead to enforcement action against the organization in question and any responsible
individuals (including (unlimited) criminal fines and the potential for imprisonment of individuals), which are not
covered by way of an indemnity and/or insurance. Claims for personal injury caused as a result of exposure to
ACMs may also be brought by third parties. We have a planned maintenance visit in place for all sites containing
asbestos where we have a repairing liability. Each year the stability of the asbestos is assessed on site and, if
required, remedial action will be taken to either further encapsulate or remove any asbestos that has become
unstable. All contractors attending site for maintenance have access to our asbestos surveys and are required to
view these surveys as part of their risk assessment and have to act accordingly. In addition, prior to any major
investment we undertake a refurbishment and demolition asbestos survey that checks the area to be developed for
the presence of any asbestos.

**_Fire_**

Pursuant to the Regulatory Reform (Fire Safety) Order 2005, as employers and/or persons in control of premises
(“responsible persons”) we have duties to take such fire precautions as are reasonably practicable to ensure the
safety of employees and third parties and to carry out a fire risk assessment. Conviction for a

breach of the 2005 Order may attract substantial fines and penalties. Our fire risk assessments are up to date and
regularly reviewed to ensure that all significant risks of potential fires are addressed and managed accordingly.

**_Legionella_**

We have a duty to manage the risk of exposure to legionella bacteria exposure under the Control of Substances
Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations and other health and safety legislation. Risk assessments that cover
L8 guidance are carried out on planned maintenance visits every two years.

**_Energy Saving Opportunity Scheme (ESOS)_**

We are subject to the Energy Saving Opportunity Scheme Regulations 2014 and we are fully compliant with
reporting requirements under the Energy Saving Opportunity Scheme (“ESOS”). We completed the ESOS survey
with Carbon Trust and logged compliance with the Environment Agency. In addition, we are planning for the

131


-----

upcoming ESOS Phase 3 compliance set for 2024. We have embraced this initiative and have taken learning from
all of the energy saving opportunities highlighted.

**_Energy Performance Certificates (EPC)_**

We are aware of our obligations under the Energy Efficiency (Private Rented Property) (England and Wales)
Regulations 2015 (the “Regulations”) which are designed to secure energy efficiency improvements to properties
in England and Wales with an energy performance rating presently of F or G on their Energy Performance
Certificate (“EPC”). We are aware that EPC standards are likely to increase in the future and are proactively
managing the future requirements of EPCs. Where low efficiencies are identified we are seeking to prioritize those
by investing in remedial works.

**_Litigation_**

We have been and, from time to time, may continue to become party to claims, proceedings and lawsuits incidental
to the ordinary course of our business.

**Board Practices**

The Group is overseen by the board of directors of the Parent, the parent company of the Group, which is
responsible for setting the Group’s direction through the establishment of strategies, key policies, and the approval
of financial objectives and targets. Furthermore, the Parent’s board of directors monitors the implementation of
strategies and policies through a structured approach of reporting by senior management and recognizes the
importance of managing relationships with various stakeholders. Moreover, the Parent’s board of directors meets
on a monthly basis and reviews strategy, operating and capital budgets, operating results and other matters relating
to the Group’s overall objectives. Additional board meetings are held during the year if required.

**Committees of the Group**

**_Managing Director Executive Committee_**

The Group’s Managing Director executive committee is chaired by the Group’s managing directors and is
composed of the Group’s chief commercial officer, human resources director, head of finance and eleven of the
Group’s operations directors. The Managing Director executive committee meets every month and its principal
role is to discuss the performance of the business and operational initiatives. This committee is also the first point
of approval for the Group’s proposed investment capital expenditure programs.

**_Operations Board_**

The Group’s operations board is chaired by its chief executive officer and is composed of its chief financial officer,
strategy, legal and business development, managing directors, chief commercial officer and human resources
director. The operations board meets every month and its principal role is to discuss the performance of business
and marketing plans, and approve any new purchasing agreements. This committee also authorizes proposed
investment capital expenditure programs to be presented at strategic planning committee meetings.

**_Strategic Planning Committee_**

The Group’s strategic planning committee is chaired by its chairman and is composed of the members of the
operations board and representatives of TDR Capital. The strategic planning committee meets every month and
its principal role is to determine the strategy of the Group and review the performance of the business against
established goals. This committee also serves as the final point of authorization for any proposed investment
capital expenditure programs.

**_Risk Management Committee_**

The Group’s risk management committee is chaired by its head of risk and is composed of representatives from
its property, food, operations, commercial and finance departments. The risk management committee meets every
three months and its principal role is to monitor the risks facing the industry and the business and to evaluate and
develop strategies to respond to, and mitigate, such risk. This committee also monitors and reports on latest
developments in regulation to which the Group’s business operations are subject.

**Conflicts of Interest**

We believe that there are currently no conflicts of interest between the duties owed by executive management to
us and their private interests. Certain of the directors are representatives of TDR Capital, which is our indirect
majority shareholder. In certain situations, the interests of TDR Capital, as indirect majority shareholder, may
differ from the interests of our other shareholders. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Structure—The
_interests of our controlling shareholder may differ from the interests of the holders of the Notes.”_

**Compensation**

The aggregate compensation paid by the Group to its directors and key management personnel for the 52 weeks
ended September 24, 2023 was £5 million, comprising their aggregate salaries and short term benefits, postemployment pension benefits and redundancy payments made during this period.

The Group has established an incentive program for key employees to help meet its strategic objectives, reward
superior performance and encourage achievement of personal objectives. The program incentivizes such key
employees through an annual cash bonus program linked to the Group’s key financial performance measures.

**Management Incentive Program**

Pursuant to a management incentive program that was implemented in February 2013, certain members of the
Group’s senior management were issued Class B ordinary shares of Midco. Under this program, the Group
extended cash loans to certain members of its senior management in order for them to purchase these shares.

In February 2019, the Group implemented a management incentive program, under which certain existing and
new members of the Group’s management purchased Class B ordinary shares of Midco. This management
incentive program replaced the old one and has substantially similar terms and conditions. For example, in the
event of a transfer of all the shares of the Group, an initial public offering, an asset sale of all or substantially all
of the Group’s assets, or a liquidation, these managers will be entitled to receive proceeds based on their respective
holdings of ordinary B shares calculated based on the sale price. In addition, the new management incentive
program includes good and bad leaver provisions in the event that a manager leaves the Group. Depending on the
cause and time of leaving, managers may receive a payment between the fair market value of their investment and
the initial investment cost.

The Group has implemented a new management incentive program in connection with the Ei Acquisition. Under
this management incentive program, the Class B ordinary shares previously held by certain members of the
Group’s management in Midco have been exchanged for Class B ordinary shares of Stonegate Holdings, an
indirect parent company of Midco and the Parent. In addition, the managers have transferred the legal title to their
shares held in Stonegate Holdings to a nominee. The nominee holds the shares in Stonegate Holdings on trust for
the managers, who retain beneficial title to the shares. Further, the rights attaching to the shares held by managers
were enhanced, for which managers paid fair market value. In addition, certain select senior employees of Ei
Group, who continued their employment with the Group, subscribed for Class B ordinary shares as part of the
management incentive program.

The Group may change the terms and conditions of its management incentive program and may introduce
additional measures to incentivize its management going forward. From time to time, the Group may also include
new managers under its management incentive program.

**Revolving Facilities Agreement**

**_Revolving Facilities_**

On or prior to the Issue Date (the “Effective Date”), certain amendments will be made to the Revolving Facilities
Agreement pursuant to the RCF Amendment Agreement, such that with effect from the Effective Date it will
provide for multicurrency credit facilities in an aggregate amount of £273,277,273 (of which (i) £25,000,000 will
be provided as a bilateral overdraft facility by Barclays Bank PLC, and (ii) £379,800 will be provided as a rent
guarantee by Barclays Bank PLC, in each case pursuant to the ancillary facility mechanic) (the “Revolving
**Facilities”). The Revolving Facilities may be drawn by way of cash advances or the issue of letters of credit or**
ancillary facilities. The Revolving Facilities may be used towards the general corporate purposes and/or the
working capital requirements of the Group (as defined under “Description of the Notes”) (including for any
acquisitions or capital expenditure).

In addition, the Parent may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional tranches of
the Revolving Facilities (the “Revolving Incremental Facilities”). The Parent and the lenders in respect of the
Revolving Incremental Facilities may agree to certain terms in relation to the Revolving Incremental Facilities,
including the margin and the termination date (subject to parameters as set out in the Revolving Facilities
Agreement). The indebtedness incurred under the Revolving Incremental Facilities must be otherwise permitted
under the Revolving Facilities Agreement.

**_Maturity and Availability Period_**

The Revolving Facilities will mature on January 31, 2029 (the “Maturity Date”).

The Revolving Facilities are available to be drawn from and including the Issue Date to and including one (1)
month prior to the Maturity Date.

**_Interest and fees_**

Loans under the Revolving Facilities Agreement initially bear interest at the aggregate of 3.00% per annum and
(in the case of loans in pound sterling) SONIA or (in the case of loans in euros) EURIBOR or (in the case of loans
in US dollars) SOFR, as applicable.

The margin for each loan under the Revolving Facilities Agreement is subject to adjustment by reference to the
consolidated senior secured leverage ratio as shown in the quarterly financial statements or, as the case may be,
the annual financial statements for that relevant period and the related compliance certificate, to equal the rate per
annum set out in the following table:


**(£ in millions)**

Greater than 4.75:1.00 ................................................................................................................................................. 3.00

Equal to or less than 4.75:1.00 but greater than 4.25:1.00 ........................................................................................... 2.75

Equal to or less than 4.25:1.00 .................................................................................................................................... 2.50

Following an initial public offering ............................................................................................................................. 2.25

The margin on any loans under the Revolving Incremental Facilities will be agreed between the Parent and the

If SONIA, EURIBOR or SOFR (as applicable) and the applicable credit adjustment spread is less than zero,
SONIA, EURIBOR or SOFR (as applicable) and the applicable credit adjustment spread shall be deemed to be
